title: 2013 Ford E-Series
subTitle: Old-school full-size van just keeps rolling along.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Ford E-Series
promoTeaser: 2013 Ford E-Series
metaTitle: 2013 Ford E-Series -- Buyer's Guide -- JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Learn about the 2013 Ford E-Series Truck in the Buyer's Guide at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Ford has been making its E-Series full-size van for more than three decades, and there’s a reason for that. Although the big box may not boast up-to-the-minute looks, it’s as stalwart a work companion as ever. The E-Series comes in a plethora of types, similar to the F-Series truck lineup. E-150, E-250 Super Duty, and E-350 Super Duty versions are available in both standard and extended lengths and in both wagon (passenger vehicle) and van (work truck) versions. In wagon form, there are side windows, while the van version’s sides are an unbroken expanse of sheet metal other than the front-seat side windows. Even though the E-Series has been around forever, there are modern conveniences including anti-lock brakes, a navigation system with 6.5-inch touchscreen, and Ford’s SYNC hands-free telematics system. The Crew Chief system is an option that helps commercial users manage a fleet of vehicles and the related data such as fuel usage and maintenance records. There’s nothing lyrical about an E-Series, unless you have a whole lot of stuff to cart around, in which case its capaciousness could just be music to your ears.

Competitors:
1.	Chevrolet Express
2.	GMC Savana

Cool Tech items 
1. Touchscreen display

Looks 
1. 178-degree opening rear cargo doors
Fun-O-Meter 2

title: Drowsiness Detection Systems
subTitle: Wake up and smell the coffee.
promoTeaserSmall: Do carmakers have to draw you a picture of a cup of coffee to get you to take a break when you're sleepy? Apparently so.
promoTeaser: Do carmakers have to draw you a picture of a cup of coffee to get you to take a break when you're sleepy? Apparently so.
metaTitle: Drowsiness Detection Systems - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Drowsiness Detection Systems: Jean Knows Cars runs down the list of driver alert systems to keep drowsy drivers from getting into an accident.

contributors.bio: Despite the fact that I grew up just outside of Detroit, I was never particularly infatuated with cars. It wasn't until I headed to Washington, D.C., and began working for an environmental trade journal that I got an up close and personal look at what it takes to design an automobile. My first articles focused on efforts by legislators to make once heavily polluting cars run cleaner. When I moved back to Michigan, that became my focus as I contributed extensively to the Detroit bureaus of both the New York Times and Newsweek. I became fascinated by how the automobile impacts so many aspects of our lives and reflects our styles and preferences. Over the past two dozen years as a freelancer, I've covered the auto industry for a wide variety of publications, including Popular Mechanics, Scientific American, iVillage, Automotive News, Ad Age, Hemispheres, Technology Review, and AARP. I've also contributed pieces on air to public radio. My coverage has focused on such issues as the ways domestic automakers will respond to increasingly tough mandates for fuel-efficient cars while still designing vehicles that appeal to consumers, and my firsthand—and slightly scary—experience driving an autonomous car. But my stories are less about the vehicle than the person driving it. I'm most intrigued by the way people shape cars and cars shape those who drive them.

pageElements.text:
If you sometimes find yourself rolling the window down to stay awake on long drives, you're not alone. In 2009, an estimated 30,000 injury crashes involved drowsy drivers, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. But some of those crashes may soon be able to be averted, thanks to new technologies that address drowsy driving. It's one of a host of new active safety alerts that are now appearing on cars. After extensive time researching the best way to diagnose and address drowsy driving, several automakers are starting to roll out systems intended to let you know when you should take a break. While these are starting out on high-end models, they're expected to filter down to more mainstream vehicles in the coming years. 
	
  Here's a glimpse at the various systems intended to address drowsy driving.

images.caption: Great minds think alike: Lincoln's drowsiness alert system.
Volvo's system is categorical.
Mercedes-Benz asks politely.

pageElements.text:
Volvo

Volvo was the first to market with a system. Its Driver Alert Control appeared on the 2008 S80, XC70, and V70. It's now offered as a part of a technology package option of $2,100 on the 2013 S60, S80, XC60, and XC70.Volvo uses a camera mounted behind the rear-view mirror that looks at road markings, along with a combination of inputs including steering movements and use of the accelerator and brake pedals to determine drowsiness. A set of five bars, similar to those indicating cell phone reception, appear in the dashboard. When those bars diminish to two, drivers will hear an audible chime, similar but lower in volume to a door chime, and will get a written warning in the instrument panel that says "time for a break" along with a coffee cup. Volvo was aiming for a more "gentle" sound that wouldn't scare and alarm the driver, which could cause an abrupt reaction in driving, said Adam Kopstein, who manages the North American Safety Office of Volvo Cars North America. He says the system is helping Volvo to achieve its ambitious long-term goal of designing a vehicle that doesn't crash.

Mercedes-Benz

Mercedes rolled out drowsiness detection in 2009, in the 2010 E-Class. Its "Attention Assist" creates a driver profile within 20 minutes of driving, which forms the baseline in determining how the driver operates the vehicle. The system uses a steering sensor, along with software that tracks 70 inputs, including such details as where the vehicle is in the lane, how often the driver adjusts the radio controls and moves the steering wheel, and how long they've been driving. The algorithm constantly compares how the driver performs to the baseline to decide when to set off the alert. When the system identifies erratic steering corrections attributable to drowsy driving, it triggers an audible warning and a "Time for a Rest" message with a coffee cup on the instrument panel. The system is standard on all 2013 C-, CL-, E-, GL-, GLK-, M-, S-, SL-, and SLK-Class vehicles. Kaity Aurilio, assistant product manager of infotainment and safety technology strategy at Mercedes-Benz USA, said the inputs were gathered through 10,000 hours of testing on driver simulators by 640 students in Germany, which identified the key indicators of fatigue.

Ford Motor Company

Ford's "Driver Alert" is packaged with a lane keeping system and is offered on the 2013 Fusion and Explorer Limited as well as the 2013 Lincoln MKS and MKT. It's also in the 2013 MKZ. It's offered as part of a $1,000 driver assist option on the Fusion and a $4,600 Lincoln technology package option that includes several high-tech features. It uses a forward-facing camera mounted behind the rear view mirror that tracks the lane lines. Driver Alert uses an algorithm to determine how much you're weaving and has five different vigilance levels. If you get to the fifth one, an alert will pop up on the instrument cluster that says "rest suggested" along with a coffee cup icon. If the driver continues the same pattern of erratic driving, a secondary warning says "rest recommended" with the coffee cup. Ford decided to package this with its lane keeping alert and lane keeping aid system because it uses the same sensor. Extensive testing of drivers who went without sleep for 24 hours and then used a driving simulator demonstrated that "erratic driving in and out of a lane was the most robust indicator of drowsiness," said Jeff Greenberg, Ford's senior technical leader of research and advanced engineering. He says Ford decided to go with a suggestion for rest because NHTSA found only two strategies that effectively addressed drowsiness: caffeine and a nap of 20 minutes or more. "We can't advise you to take a nap but we can advise you to take a break," he said. Ford nixed an audible alarm, since "there is enough beeping at you in the car," he said.

BMW of North America

BMW offers "Attention Assistant" as standard on its 2013 7 Series. The system operates similarly to the others on the market, measuring a variety of driver inputs, such as steering, on an ongoing basis looking for deviations. When a pattern is detected, it offers an audible tone, along with the words, "Break Recommended" in the display.

Automakers have experimented with a variety of ways to wake up drowsy drivers, including emitting an aroma through the dashboard. But that ultimately has yet to be used. Paul Green, Research Professor with the University of  Michigan Transportation Research Institute Driver Interface Group, says the drawback of aromas is that it takes time to dispense them and controlling their delivery to the driver and others is not easy.

Eye movement was one of the original ways to detect drowsiness, and it's being used as a measure in a system being developed by automotive supplier Denso International America, Inc. -- and yet to appear on cars -- which has adopted facial expression as the drowsiness index. Using a camera located on the dashboard, it monitors percentage of eye closure time and heart rate, along with lane deviation. Greenberg says though the scientific basis of eye closure systems is very sound, "technically and practically being able to implement that and accurately focus the camera on the driver's eye to yield an appropriate calculation is quite challenging." He says there are also issues with older drivers who have droopy eyelids, where it's tough to get a clear picture of the eye.

The technology that most suppliers and automakers are developing is based on lane tracking, not monitoring the driver's face, said David Zuby, chief research officer at the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. He says "the jury is still out" on whether these systems are making roads safer. He says while the warning may help drivers recognize they're tired before they're aware of it, "in most cases, people will ignore the suggestion because they know they're tired, but just want to get home," instead of stopping to take a rest.

title: Bosch Car Clinic
subTitle: First JKC ride-and-drive event earns our young journalist her wings.
promoTeaserSmall: JKC's first official participation in a ride-and-drive event earns our young journalist her wings.
promoTeaser: JKC's first official participation in a ride-and-drive event earns our young journalist her wings.
metaTitle: Bosch Car Clinic--JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Bosch Car Clinic: Find out about Bosch's technology work for automakers, as shown during a ride-and-drive event. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: If you’ve ever wondered what it’s like to be an auto journalist, well, that makes two of us. Most of my experience lies in reading public policy studies and sifting through zoning codes to unearth de jure injustices, so the fact that my job requires me to spend the whole day thinking about cars is still novel. Just don’t ask my bosses why they hired me, or they might change their minds.

After a few weeks getting my sea legs, I was thrown to the sharks at a ride-and-drive event at the extensive proving ground of Robert Bosch, LLC, in beautiful Flat Rock, Michigan. (People kept saying that to me as a joke, but I want to clarify that Flat Rock actually is beautiful, in a very Michigan sort of way: two-lane roads lined with judgmental cows and that sort of thing.)
When I got the assignment, I really wasn’t sure what to expect, but I did know that I might get to drive a few cars, which, in my book, is a good enough reason to go anywhere.

If you think of Bosch as a supplier of dishwashers and stereos, you’re missing a huge part of the picture. The company is sprawling, but a large part of what it does is research, develop, and sell technology to auto manufacturers. This company is behind the windshield wipers on the Ford Focus and the information and entertainment system in Cadillacs. Bosch is also at the forefront in developing fuel-saving and safety technologies. The company also helps make Bombardier’s seriously cool three-wheeled Spyder safer from rollovers.

When I walked through the door, after parking my war-weary Chevy among the shiny, comparatively expensive automobiles that filled the rest of the parking lot, I knew some of this, but not all of it. I was interested in Bosch’s involvement in clean diesel technology (you should be, too), and I’m not ashamed to say I was really, really excited to drive some cars.

The first order of the day was breakfast, which was really just built-in networking time. It became immediately clear to me that most of the people in the room had not only met before, but in many cases had been working in the same industry for years or even decades. I had been working in this industry for approximately six weeks, but luckily my new colleagues have proven to be a kind and welcoming bunch. I got a lot of questions about Jean Knows Cars, which almost no one had heard of, since we were still deep in the task of launching at the time. One man looked at my name tag a little skeptically, then said, “I’ve never read any of your stuff.” He laughed when I told him that no one had yet.

images.caption: Flat Rock, MI
Flat Rock, MI
Flat Rock, MI
Flat Rock, MI

pageElements.text: Next was the meat and potatoes: eight stations, rotating counterclockwise, with technical experts explaining some of their coolest, most innovative technology. Some of this was right up my alley: I’d done research on start/stop technology, I’d used Cadillac Cue, and I was familiar with emergency braking systems. In other areas, I was woefully out of my depth. DC/DC converters? I’m pretty sure they have something to do with electricity. Alternators? Might be related to the engine? The different operating modes of internal-combustion engines? Yeah, no. I tried to soak it all in, and I took comfort knowing that many of the rest of my cohorts were just as confused as I was. We were liberal arts majors all around, as far as I could tell: the type of people who were just smart enough to figure out they weren’t smart enough to engineer drivetrains.

I actually learned a lot. Mostly, I learned that engineers are well aware that most consumers want to lower their fuel consumption without giving up any driving enjoyment, and luckily for us, they have a lot of ideas about how to make that happen.

Bosch is poised to benefit from new fuel regulations that will require passenger vehicles to average 31.6 miles per gallon by 2013, with a huge jump to 54.5 miles per gallon in 2025. Bosch believes that its start/stop technology, which allows a vehicle’s engine to turn off while the car is stopped and then seamlessly re-engage when the gas is depressed, can lead to fuel savings of up to 15 percent in city traffic.

Bosch is also involved in bringing diesel technology to the North American market, and the company is determined to recast diesel’s negative image in the United States. Diesel engines in lightweight vehicles (not the pickups and semis we’re used to seeing them in) can add up to 200 miles to the life of a tank of gas, according to the preliminary results of a study Bosch cited from the University of Michigan Transportation Research Institute.  The technology is spreading from luxury manufacturers like Audi and BMW to other makes, including Volkswagen, Mazda, Jeep, and Chevrolet. Bosch says that there will be more than twenty diesel launches in 2013--with fifty-four diesel launches scheduled between now and 2017.

Bosch also works on products designed to make the driving experience safer, like forward collision mitigation, which can slow a car down ahead of a collision to reduce damage, and adaptive cruise control to maintain an automatic safe following distance from the vehicle ahead. If there is danger of a front collision, the technology can give a visual or auditory warning and briefly apply the brakes to make sure the driver is paying attention. Kay Stepper, director of driver assistance engineering, said the company has a “vision of accident-free driving” and hopes that technology like this can reduce the number of crashes--currently up to 90 percent--that are due to driver error.

After a lunch break came the driving. Much of my young life has been spent practically begging people with nicer cars than me for their keys. I have occasionally invented minor car trouble for a seat behind the wheel of my father’s Volkswagen (“I hear a weird ticking noise under the passenger seat… Will you trade cars with me?”). The idea that I could just walk up to any car I wanted and drive it around what essentially amounts to a small racetrack was almost too much to believe. I kept thinking, “Don’t these people realize they’ve just turned the car over to a total fiend?”

Apparently not, because even after I giggled a little while behind the wheel of a turbo-diesel Volkswagen Beetle, they just kept opening the doors. I also drove a surprisingly sprightly turbocharged Ford Escape, two different Mercedes-Benzes with impressive start/stop technology, a Ford Focus with fancy windshield wipers, and a Peugeot 3008 HYbrid4. (When I was coming around the track’s banked curve in the Peugeot, the engineer in the passenger seat said, “Now slowly accelerate up to 50.” Then he realized I was already going almost 60 mph. Whoops.)
All in all, it wasn’t a bad way to spend the morning. I would encourage the rest of you to become automotive writers, but I don’t want the secret to get out.

Ford Focus
Ford Escape
Volkswagen Beetle Turbo
Volkswagen Beetle TDI engine
Peugeot 3008 HYbrid4

title: 2013 Nissan Frontier
subTitle: The 2013 Nissan Frontier earns a spot on shopping lists – for now.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Nissan Frontier
promoTeaser: 2013 Nissan Frontier
metaTitle: 2013 Nissan Frontier--Buyer's Guide--Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Nissan Frontier here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Nissan Frontier is one of the top picks in a shrinking class of compact pickup trucks. But it shouldn’t rest on its laurels, since General Motors recently announced that a new GMC Canyon and Chevrolet Colorado are in the pipeline. The Frontier is a strong contender in the meantime, with good engine choices, including a 261-horsepower 4.0-liter V-6 and an optional 152-horsepower 2.5-liter inline four-cylinder engine for the base King Cab 4x2 model. A five-speed manual transmission is standard on four-cylinder models, along with an optional five-speed automatic transmission or six-speed manual transmission for the rest of the lineup. The two-wheel-drive Frontier with the four-cylinder engine and five-speed manual transmission returns good fuel economy at 19 mpg in city driving and 23 mpg on the highway, according to the EPA.  The Frontier has a maximum towing capacity of 6,500 pounds, making it a decent workhorse. Serious truckers can opt for four-wheel-drive models with a locking rear differential, tough Bilstein shock absorbers, and skid plates. The Frontier has a smooth ride and better driving dynamics than many of its rivals, but the cabin looks dated with its cheap trim. The Frontier offers plenty of truck for the money, with a fully boxed chassis, steel construction, and leaf-spring rear suspension. But it’s anybody’s guess what the Motor City has in store when it debuts its new midsize trucks.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Toyota Tacoma
2. Honda Ridgeline

New for 2013:
1. Nissan says details on the 2013 Frontier will be available at a later date. It goes in sale in early 2013.

title: 2013 Nissan Rogue
subTitle: The 2013 Nissan Rogue Gets Some Things Right – But Not Everything
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Nissan Rogue
promoTeaser: 2013 Nissan Rogue
metaTitle: 2013 Nissan Rogue--Buyer's Guide--Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Nissan Rogue here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Nissan Rogue is a stylish compact crossover that adds interest for the new model year with a new Premium Edition. This new edition adds front fog lights and a Bose audio system with seven speakers. The Rogue gets lots of credit for what it does right, including its emphasis on an attractive exterior, its spacious interior and long list of options. It is equipped with an adequate 170-horsepower 2.5-liter inline four-cylinder engine that is underpowered next to much of the competition. It also is hampered by road noise, bad rear visibility, short backseat cushions and boring cabin styling. It can be fun to drive up to a point, but the soft suspension tuning and average steering feel fall just short of truly sporty. The Rogue is family friendly with large storage areas in the cabin, an optional fold-flat passenger seat that boosts its practicality and comfortable front seats. The high seating position is a plus for a driver who wants a command position  behind the wheel. There are also benefits at the gas pump. The front-wheel-drive Rogue returns a respectable 23 mpg in city driving and 28 mpg on the highway. The four-wheel-drive Rogue returns 22 mpg in city driving and 27 mpg on the highway, according to the EPA. The Rogue is competitively priced against most of its competition, including the Honda CR-V and Volkswagen Tiguan.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Honda CR-V
2. Hyundai Tucson
3. Toyota RAV4
4. Volkswagen Tiguan

New for 2013:
1. Premium Edition replaces the previous Premium Package, adding front fog lights and Bose audio system with seven speakers.
2. Bluetooth and two additional speakers are added to Special Edition Package on S models.

title: 2013 Toyota Land Cruiser
subTitle: Behold the “bruiser cruiser”
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Toyota Land Cruiser
promoTeaser: 2013 Toyota Land Cruiser
metaTitle: 2013 Toyota Land Cruiser--Buyer's Guide--Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Toyota Land Cruiser here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Toyota Land Cruisers from the 1960s have become awfully trendy in recent years. But make no mistake, the dainty, Jeep-like runabouts that helped get Toyota on its feet in America forty-fvive years ago are nothing at all like their 2013 namesake. Whereas the original Land Cruiser was light, simple, and lived to go topless, the new Land Cruiser is a serious and scholarly fixed-roof, seven-seater, cruising the land, so to speak, laden with more technology than all but the most expensive luxury automobiles in the world. As such, the Land Cruiser reigns supreme within Toyota’s six-member SUV hierarchy, above the Sequoia, 4Runner, Highlander, FJ Cruiser, and RAV4. And it doesn’t look to be ready to surrender its throne any time soon, with 2013 bringing an updated grille, new headlamps, and LED accent lights to convey an even more upscale appearance. It also contains even more luxury inside—all standard, by the way—in the form of ventilated perforated leather-covered front seats, a heated steering wheel, voice-activated navigation, Toyota’s EnTune app suite, and new gauges with a super-cool multi-terrain monitor. Mechanical upgrades for 2013 include a retuned suspension, radar-based cruise control, trailer-sway control, and pre-collision safety system. What hasn’t changed? The 381-horsepower V-8 is as grunty (and thirsty) as ever, and thanks to new multi-terrain engine and braking management systems, it is still one of the most capable off-roaders in the world.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Land Rover Range Rover
2. Lexus LX570
3. Cadillac Escalade

Cool Tech items :
1. Multi-terrain monitor presents front-, side- and rearviews for proper wheel location off-road.
2. Mutli-terrain powertrain and brake system management.
3. Pre-collision safety system.

Looks :
1. Revised grille and headlamps.
2. LED front accent lighting.
3. Upgraded interior materials, including higher-gloss wood grain and chrome-plated air vents.

title: Dealer vs. Mechanic
subTitle: Some pros and cons for you
promoTeaserSmall: When your car breaks down, where should you take it?
promoTeaser: When your car breaks down, where should you take it?
metaTitle: Dealer vs. Mechanic - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Dealer vs. Mechanic: How do you decide whether it's better to take your car to the dealership or a mechanic when it needs to be serviced? Here are some pros and cons. The story is on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Despite the fact that I grew up just outside of Detroit, I was never particularly infatuated with cars. It wasn't until I headed to Washington, D.C., and began working for an environmental trade journal that I got an up close and personal look at what it takes to design an automobile. My first articles focused on efforts by legislators to make once heavily polluting cars run cleaner. When I moved back to Michigan, that became my focus as I contributed extensively to the Detroit bureaus of both the New York Times and Newsweek. I became fascinated by how the automobile impacts so many aspects of our lives and reflects our styles and preferences. Over the past two dozen years as a freelancer, I've covered the auto industry for a wide variety of publications, including Popular Mechanics, Scientific American, iVillage, Automotive News, Ad Age, Hemispheres, Technology Review, and AARP. I've also contributed pieces on air to public radio. My coverage has focused on such issues as the ways domestic automakers will respond to increasingly tough mandates for fuel-efficient cars while still designing vehicles that appeal to consumers, and my firsthand—and slightly scary—experience driving an autonomous car. But my stories are less about the vehicle than the person driving it. I'm most intrigued by the way people shape cars and cars shape those who drive them.

pageElements.text: When Nancy Baum and her husband were in the market for a new car, one of the most important criteria was "whether it could be serviced by Joe." Joe is Joe Bird, the owner of Japanese Auto Professional Service, Ltd., an independent repair shop in Ann Arbor, Michigan, where Baum and her husband have been taking their Hondas and Toyotas for ten years. Their interest in buying local caused them to consider purchasing their first American car, a Ford Fusion. "But then we realized Joe's only does Japanese cars,” Baum said. So, just before Labor Day weekend, they bought a 2012 Toyota Camry Hybrid instead. Baum says that Bird is the kind of neighborhood mechanic who is incredibly honest, vetoing repairs that aren't essential. She estimates he charged "hundreds of dollars less" for services than the dealer.

Finding an honest place to take your car for service and repairs can be daunting. While Baum's story resonates with the many who have found the perfect local independent mechanic, others wouldn't think of leaving their car with anyone but a trusted dealer technician. Still, some find the technician who can promptly and effectively handle a repair and charge a reasonable price elusive.

So how can you find an honest technician who performs high-quality work? Not surprisingly, dealers believe they're best equipped to provide service. “We want to take really good care of our customers so they continue to want to buy vehicles from us,” says Annette Sykora, owner of Smith South Plains dealership in Levelland, Texas. She said factory training for dealer technicians is extensive, so customers can be certain they’re getting someone who is qualified to do the job. She said that she, and most all dealers, surveys the landscape constantly to ensure she's competitively priced.

Independent service shop owners feel they're more than equipped to do any job. Bill Moss, owner of Ferris EuroService in Warrenton, Virginia, and a board member of the Automotive Service Association, says at independent shops, consumers will likely speak to an owner who has a stake in the service experience. The average ASA member consists of companies with under five employees. He also says he has less overhead than the dealer: "I'm not paying for all the tinted glass and marble floors," he says, so his prices tend to be ten percent less. Nikki Ayers, owner of Ayers Automotive Repair in Santa Barbara, California and executive director of The Independent Automotive Professional Association, which represents over 100 independent shops, said there's "nothing that an independent mechanic can't do."

But a March 2012 U.S. Customer Service Index by J.D. Power and Associates found that vehicle owners who visit dealers for service are far more satisfied than those who went to independent facilities. Customers of dealer facilities found satisfaction with the overall dealer experience was 38 points higher on a 1,000-point scale compared with non-dealer facilities. "Manufacturers and dealers have put a lot of investment into the customer experience in the past few years and we see that reflected in the scores," said Chris Sutton, senior director of J.D. Power's automotive retail practice.

Tricia Hecker, head of marketing at Mopar, Chrysler's service arm, says that dealers are well qualified to perform whatever type of service you need. "We make sure that if you come in for a brake job, you'll get a technician certified to perform one," she said. "If you go to an independent repair shop, there's no guarantee," since the smaller shops may not be equipped to service all the types of jobs that come through their door. She said there's such a range in the independent sector, it's hard to know the quality you're getting, while at the dealer, you can be assured the service is top-notch. She also says there's no significant difference in cost, despite the commonly held perception that dealer service is higher and customers are assured use of original equipment manufacturer parts, which are typically of higher quality.

Ayers acknowledges that the quality could vary significantly among independent shops. One key to look for, she says, is Automotive Service Excellence certifications. She has seven master technicians certified at her shop in the required eight areas: Engine Repair; Automatic Transmission/Transaxle; Manual Drive Train & Transaxle; Suspension & Steering; Brakes;  Electrical/Electronic Systems;  Heating & Air Conditioning;  and Engine Performance. The ASE certification is the gold standard, designed to provide a yardstick for consumers to be able to identify the individuals that have the knowledge necessary to repair their vehicles properly the first time, says Tony Molla, a spokesman for The National Institute for Automotive Service Excellence, the organization providing the certifications. He says over 370,000 technicians working in both dealerships and independent repair shops have this certification. While dealers represent only 30 percent of the repair business, a larger proportion of dealer technicians are certified. He said, though, that independent shops are typically less expensive and consumers find it to be a less intimidating experience than going to a dealer. But "both segments do an outstanding job servicing the vehicle fleet," he said.
Even so, there are some instances where it might make sense to go either to a dealer or independent repair shop.

If your car is under a factory warranty and you have a repair that falls under the warranty, only an authorized dealer can perform the repairs free of charge. The same goes for factory recalls, which can only be performed for free at dealerships.
There are some jobs that independents won't do, and if they're honest, they'll recommend you go to a dealership, Molla says.
For older cars, over ten years old, an independent mechanic who has more experience with these types of vehicles may be better suited to service them, Molla says.
For higher end cars, customers may prefer to the dealerships, though there are some "talented independent repair shops" that specialize in certain car models, he says.
Tips for Selecting a High Quality Service Facility Here's a checklist of measures you can take to find the facility -- be it independent mechanic or dealer -- that's right for you.

Check to make sure technicians are ASE certified and make sure they have the certification in the area of expertise that your car requires. Certificates may be posted in the waiting area that also lists when it expires, since technicians have to re-qualify every five years. There may also be a sign in front. If not, you can ask.
See if they're part of an industry trade group, like ASA or whether they're approved by AAA.
Check with the Better Business Bureau to see if the facility has been subject to any complaints.
Check out the reviews on the Internet. That's a "huge, third party indicator of people's experience," Moss says.

Look for professionals with good customer service skills. Make sure you're treated well. Also, do you feel comfortable asking questions about issues you don't understand? The technician should be able to communicate the service being performed and how much it will cost clearly and should be receptive to any questions you have. "Handling female customers is the constant source of seminars," Moss says. If the technician is condescending or sexist, go elsewhere. Molla points out that only one percent of technicians are female, so chances are you'll be dealing with a male.

Is the shop clean and well organized? This matters more to some than others. Nancy Baum was willing to overlook the disheveled waiting area in her favorite repair shop. "It feels very earnest to me. There's a bunch of people working hard and not putting a lot of money into having a fancy waiting room." But if you're seeking a clean, spacious waiting room to wait for your car, the facility ambience will be more important.

Ask your friends, neighbors and co-workers for their advice. Rich White, executive director of The Car Care Council, which oversees the Be Car Care Aware campaign that educates consumers on the benefits of regular vehicle maintenance and repair, says you can get tips from those you know and respect the most, asking where they take their car and if they're happy with the service.

Check out the cars in the parking lot and those being serviced, to see if they're similar to yours. "If you've got a Honda, you don't want to go to a place specializing in domestic vehicles," White says.
Try out a facility with simpler repairs like oil changes or tire rotations so you'll have a sense of whether you like them before you need a major repair.
For more ideas on what to look for in a repair shop, go to carcare.org
A list of repair facilities can also be found on CARQUEST's TechNet site: www.techauto.com

title: 2013 Mazda 6 at the Paris Auto Show
subTitle: The 2013 Mazda 6, as I saw it in Paris: a sportier alternative to mainstream sedans.
promoTitle: 2013 Mazda 6 at the Paris Auto Show
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Mazda 6
promoTeaser: 2013 Mazda 6
metaTitle: 2013 Mazda 6 in Paris -- JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: See the 2013 Mazda 6 unveiled at the Paris Auto Show. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/fQJ6zZWskz8?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

The Mazda 6 has always been an excellent choice if you’re the type of person who cringes when you see another person wearing the same dress that you have on at a party. With the Japanese midsize sedan, you won’t see yourself coming and going on the road like you will with some of the domestic competition. Mazda is in somewhat of a holding pattern with the Mazda 6 at this point, since a fully redesigned model is on tap for the 2014 model year. In the meantime, there are no significant changes to the Mazda 6. The current generation sedan has a striking presence, with a long hood and flared front fenders. Mazda pitches it as being “sexy, yet sensible.” The base car is nicely equipped with standard air conditioning, power accessories, cruise control and a stereo system with six speakers. The base Mazda 6 is equipped with a 170-horsepower 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine linked to a six-speed manual transmission. The top-of-the-line model gets a 272-horsepower 3.7-liter V6 engine linked to a six-speed automatic transmission. There are numerous options, including a rear spoiler, remote engine start on automatic-transmission models, pearl exterior paint and a power moonroof. A $1,785 technology package bundles several items, including LED rear lights, heated side mirrors and a power front passenger’s seat. On the downside, there is no hybrid option as there is with some of the competition.

title: 2013 Land Rover Range Rover
subTitle: The 2013 Range Rover: Less Weight, Bigger Price Tag
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Land Rover Range Rover
promoTeaser: 2013 Land Rover Range Rover
metaTitle: 2013 Land Rover Range Rober--Buyer's Guide--JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Learn about the 2013 Land Rover Range Rover in the Buyer's Guide at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Range Rover went through an extreme makeover, shedding 700 pounds. Parent Jaguar Land Rover calls it the world’s first SUV with an all-aluminum structure. The dramatic changes are expected to deliver a significant improvement in fuel economy, although the EPA has not yet released any official numbers. The outgoing model with a 5.0-liter V-8 and six-speed automatic transmission returns a dismal 12 mpg in city driving. The 2013 Range Rover gets carryover V-8 engines enhanced by new eight-speed ZF automatic transmissions. The redesigned Range Rover also gets a re-engineered four-corner air suspension and new suspension architecture to deliver flatter cornering abilities. The cabin gets tweaked as well, with rear legroom increased by 4.7 inches. A two-place rear seating package is optional. The new Range Rover also borrows some design cues from the glamorous Range Rover Evoque. Plus there are 37 exterior paint choices. You may reach for the smelling salts once you check out the sticker price, however. The redesigned 2013 Range Rover starts at $83,500, including an $850 destination charge, reflecting a $3,225 increase over the outgoing model. The top-of-the-line Range Rover Autobiography starts at $130,950, including shipping, reflecting a $4,285 increase over the outgoing model. On the plus side, the Range Rover is priced lower than one of its chief rivals, the 2013 Mercedes-Benz GL550, which starts at $87,805, including a $905 destination charge.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Mercedes-Benz GL550
2. Audi Q7
3. Infiniti QX56
4. Lexus LX 570

Cool Tech:
1. Optional Dynamic Response active lean control system minimizes body roll.
2. Surround Camera system gives amazing view of exterior, including trailer hitch guidance.

New for 2013:
1. Exterior cues borrowed from Range Rover Evoque.
2. New, eight-speed ZF automatic transmissions.
3. New, all-aluminum unibody structure.
4. Re-engineered four-corner air suspension.

title: 2013 Land Rover LR4
subTitle: The 2013 Land Rover LR4: British Cachet, Rugged Capability
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Land Rover LR4
promoTeaser: 2013 Land Rover LR4
metaTitle: 2013 Land Rover LR4--Buyer's Guide--JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Learn about the 2013 Land Rover LR4 in the Buyer's Guide at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Land Rover LR4 is one of the most capable off-roaders on the market, plus it has lots of British cachet to recommend it. But its relatively high price and lousy fuel economy – plus the fact that it requires premium fuel – may turn off some buyers. Parent Jaguar Land Rover has not announced any changes for 2013, but there aren’t likely to be many since the SUV underwent a major renovation in 2010. The LR4 gets a 375-horsepower 5.0-liter V-8 engine linked to a six-speed automatic transmission. It’s an extremely trustworthy and burly beast that can tackle snow, sand, water, or mud with ease. It has four-wheel drive and a truck-based frame and is not a practical choice if you’re just going to take it to the mall and use it for the school car pool. Off-highway driving is where it shows its mettle, thanks to an adjustable air suspension and a fancy Terrain Response system. On the plus side, it costs less than a Range Rover. The LR4 is offered with an optional third row that boosts seating capacity to seven. You can load up the LR4 with lots of amenities, including an optional third-row bench that folds into the floor and an optional rear-seat entertainment system.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. Acura MDX
2. BMW X5
3. Cadillac Escalade
4. Volkswagen Touareg

Cool Tech:
1. Terrain Response system, which tailors vehicle characteristics to accommodate driving conditions.

New for 2013:
1. Two new packages: black design package and extended leather package.
2. Five new exterior paint colors.

title: 2013 Chevrolet Express
subTitle: For those who work hard for the money and are looking only for a work vehicle.
promoTeaserSmall: For those who work hard for the money and are looking only for a work vehicle.
promoTeaser: For those who work hard for the money and are looking only for a work vehicle.
metaTitle: 2013 Chevrolet Express Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Chevrolet Express here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: If what you’re after is a hard-working van that has no pretensions of passenger comfort, Chevrolet’s Express could be exactly what you’re looking for. The Express can tow 6,200 pounds even in its most modest configuration, and it is available in so many versions that there’s sure to be one for any work application—with special packages for ambulance and hotel shuttle uses. Rear- or four-wheel-drive models are available, and in standard and extended lengths, light-duty or heavy-duty versions, and passenger or cargo versions. In its most extended form, the Express can seat  fifteen people; in its most muscle-bound form, it can tow 10,000 pounds. Its fully boxed frame gives it strength, if not beauty. The cargo version of the Express can be equipped with a compressed natural gas package, and the Express lineup also includes a choice five gas/flex-fuel engines and a turbo-diesel. Some modern touches, including a backup camera, a navigation-capable radio, and ultrasonic rear parking assist, have been added for 2013; all are optional. The chrome appearance package and optional Sirius XM satellite radio make the workday go more pleasantly, but this is no consumer-market minivan, nor does it try to be.
Fun-O-Meter: 3

Competitors:
1. Ford E-Series
2. GMC Savana
3. Nissan NV

Cool Tech Items:
1. Dedicated CNG version.
2. Computer-controlled glow plugs start turbo-diesel engine in less than three seconds in temperatures as low as negative twenty degrees Fahrenheit without a block heater.

Looks:
1. Door choices include 60/40 split-folding passenger’s and driver’s door.
2. Wheatland Yellow a new exterior color choice.
3. Chrome appearance package.

New for 2013:
1. Rear park assist, backup camera (optional).
2. Navigation radio (optional).

title: 2013 Chevrolet Sonic
subTitle: Don’t let its small size and cute appearance fool you: this car is not bad at all.
promoTeaserSmall: Don’t let its small size and cute appearance fool you: this car is not bad at all.
promoTeaser: Don’t let its small size and cute appearance fool you: this car is not bad at all.
metaTitle: 2013 Chevrolet Sonic Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Chevrolet Sonic here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Sometimes you shop for a subcompact because you’re looking for a cute first car or a nimble city transporter. Sometimes you are motivated by concern about fuel economy and a small carbon footprint. And sometimes you are just plain too broke to buy anything bigger. Don’t feel deprived: the Chevrolet Sonic is actually pretty good. Available in both sedan and hatchback body styles, the U.S.-built Sonic weighs a pretty imposing 2,600 pounds and has ten standard airbags, so it’s no lightweight either literally or figuratively. Its four-cylinder engine choices are the same as those on the larger Cruze. There’s also a turbocharged RS sport hatchback, new this year, which will go on sale in late 2012. The RS’s sportiness is telegraphed by four-wheel disc brakes, a lowered ride height, more assertive chassis and transmission setups, and a leather-trimmed interior, plus red accents and aluminum pedals. You could actually plan to carry back-seat passengers without apologizing, thanks to a relatively roomy interior. An optional Connectivity and Cruise package adds a USB port, Bluetooth audio, steering-wheel-mounted audio controls, and cruise control, and Chevrolet’s MyLink information and entertainment system is available on the uplevel LTZ model and the RS. All in all, you are sure to feel less penalized than you might have expected.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Ford Fiesta
2. Hyundai Accent
3. Kia Rio
4. Nissan Versa

Cool Tech Items:
1.“Three wet” paint process is water based, helping the environment.
2. MyLink for Sonic is an easy-to-use smartphone integrator; standard on RS and LTZ, optional on lower-end LS and LT.

Looks:
1. Sunroof, even though it’s a subcompact.
2. Rear deck-lid spoiler an option on LT, standard on LTZ.

New for 2013:
1. RS sport hatchback.

title: 2013 Toyota Tundra
subTitle: However Texan it may be, the Tundra still trails among trucks.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Toyota Tundra
promoTeaser: 2013 Toyota Tundra
metaTitle: 2013 Toyota Tundra--Buyer's Guide--Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Toyota Tundra here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Toyota has tried, and in many cases succeeded, in building the most popular cars in their respective classes. But not everything Toyota touches turns to gold, and the big, San Antonio-built Tundra is all you need for proof. Blessed as it is with Toyota’s legendary name and attendant reputation for quality, the Tundra almost overshoots the mark in terms of sheer bigness without necessarily matching the satisfying driving experience as, say, the new Ford F-150, or even the older, but more comfortable-in-their-own-skin, full-size pickups from Ram and Chevrolet/GMC. Oceans of hard plastic abound inside the Tundra, and particularly on two-door models, opening the doors can seem like moving a wall. The three available engines are strong, however, starting with a 270-horsepower V-6, 310-horsepower 4.6-liter V-8 and a 381-horsepower V-8 on the upgrade list if one needs still more grunt. While the Tundra is offered in three cab styles, three comfort grades (SR5, Limited, and Platinum), and three bed lengths, it is not offered in the bewildering array of ways one can find at any of the established American brands, and nor is the Tundra offered with a diesel engine or a heavy-duty spec.
Fun-O-Meter: 4

Competitors:
1. Nissan Titan
2. Dodge Ram
3. Ford F-150

Looks :
1. TRD Rock Warrior package: seventeen-inch wheels, color-keyed bumper/grille, fog lamps, exterior graphics, and black upholstery.
2. TRD Off-road package: skid plates, eighteen-inch wheels, and off-road suspension.
3. Glitzy wheels/billet grille/luxury-laden interior for Platinum grade.

Cool Tech items :
1. Display navigation system with Entune app suite four double cab and CrewMax models.
2. Driver and front outboard passenger knee airbags.
3. Standard solar energy-absorbing glass.

New for 2013:
1. Chrome appearance package with three wheel choices.
2. TRD Rock Warrior package now available on 4X4 Limited (previously base model only).

title: 2013 Toyota Venza
subTitle: The big-boned Camry wagonette gets a slight makeover.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Toyota Venza
promoTeaser: 2013 Toyota Venza
metaTitle: 2013 Toyota Venza--Buyer's Guide--Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Toyota Venza here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Americans love their Toyota Camry. Americans also need versatility in their family vehicles. So how better for Toyota to satisfy them all than with a Camry wagon? Unfortunately, the senselessly stigmatized station wagon would never sell, not even if it was based on the beloved Camry…that is, unless Toyota botches up, calls it a crossover, and calls it something other than “Camry wagon.” Enter the Venza, Toyota’s answer to American Camry lovers who really need a wagon but just can’t bring themselves to actually drive one. As with the Camry, the Venza is a very good car that offers Lexus-like quietness and a spacious and nicely assembled and somewhat austere cabin. It is available in three trim levels and behind its new headlamps and gaping, chrome-drenched grille is the choice of fuel-efficient four- or six-cylinder engines. Something the Venza does not inherit from the Camry is a hybrid version, but it does trump its sedan sibling by offering all-wheel drive. The Venza also provides its occupants with a taller-than-usual seating position for excellent outward vision, at least to the front (rear vision is hampered by thick pillars), while ample storage awaits out back. Families needing a third-row seat and/or an even better view of the road ahead could look at the Highlander (which, incidentally, is also Camry-based) but they won’t get as car-like an experience as offered by the Venza.
Fun-O-Meter: 4

Competitors:
1. Ford Edge
2. Honda Crosstour
3. Subaru Outback

Cool Tech items:
1. Available Display audio system with Entune app suite.
2. Available tow package.

Looks:
1. Revised head- and taillamps.
2. Revised upper and lower grilles.
3. Available Black interior.

New for 2013 :
1. Attitude Black, Cypress Pearl, Cosmic Gray.
2. New nineteen-inch wheel design.
3. Additional equipment for XLE and Limited grades.

title: 2013 Toyota Yaris
subTitle: Toyota’s subcompact appears destined to stay as is for at least another year.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Toyota Yaris
promoTeaser: 2013 Toyota Yaris
metaTitle: 2013 Toyota Yaris--Buyer's Guide--Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Toyota Yaris here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Toyota has a long history of building truly great cheap cars, but its current entry vehicle, the Yaris, is not destined to be one of them. Introduced last year as all new, the hatchback was more of a “top hat” redesign replacing the previous Yaris’s body but not the low-powered 1.5-liter engine or the somewhat dated four-speed automatic/five-speed manual transmission choices. As a result, the Yaris is underwhelming, especially considering how strong most of its competition—namely the Ford Fiesta, Chevrolet Sonic, Hyundai Accent, and Kia Rio—has become. Not helping its cause is that it falls short of the magic 40-mpg EPA highway rating, which has become something of the gold standard against which tiny cars are measured these days. That said, the Yaris looks reasonably good, especially in five-door SE form, a trim level that also brings with it some effective performance upgrades that liven up the driving experience considerably. The interior is about as fancy as you’d expect at the sub-$15,000 price point, perhaps even less. But the Yaris does appear to have something of an airbag fetish, as no fewer than nine of the inflatables come standard, including a rare-for-the-class driver’s-side knee bag. New for 2013 is the standard fitment of last year’s audio package. Otherwise, it’s more of the same.
Fun-O-Meter: 3

Competitors:
1. Chevrolet Sonic
2. Ford Fiesta
3. Nissan Versa

Cool Tech items:
1. Upgraded brakes and suspension on SE model.
2. Innovative single windshield wiper system.
3. Nine air bags standard.

Looks :
1. Two- or four-door hatchback-only body styles.
2. Spiffy styling for sport-tuned SE model.

New for 2013 :
1. Upgraded stereo now standard on all trim levels.

title: You Auto Know: NHTSA SaferCar Website
subTitle: One quick visit to the feds' SaferCar website, and you'll be on your way to finding a...safer car.
promoTitle: You Auto Know: NHTSA SaferCar Website
promoTeaserSmall: One quick visit to the feds' SaferCar website, and you'll be on your way to finding a...safer car.
promoTeaser: One quick visit to the feds' SaferCar website, and you'll be on your way to finding a...safer car.
keywords: You Auto Know: NHTSA SaferCar Website
metaTitle: You Auto Know: NHTSA SaferCar Website - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: You Auto Know: NHTSA SaferCar Website. Find out about government safety website SaferCar.gov and what it can tell  you about safety and recall information. It's at JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: This You Auto Know video could be subtitled "government sites that are actually useful." Safercar.gov is a site belonging to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, also known as NHTSA, and it has a lot of information you can use every day. Use it to find government crash test safety ratings and recall notices, but come back to it for a wealth of other information. From car seat installation details to clear explanations of rollover protection technology, you probably need it, and Safercar.gov probably has it.

title: Counterfeit Airbag Danger
promoTeaserSmall: Government warns about counterfeit air bags that may pose a serious danger if they deploy.
promoTeaser: Government warns about counterfeit air bags that may pose a serious danger if they deploy.
metaTitle: Counterfeit Airbag Danger -- JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Counterfeit Airbag Danger: Learn about a U.S. government warning on the problem counterfeit air bags can pose; it's on  JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) released a warning on October 10 that drivers who have had air bags in their car replaced in the past three years could possibly have received dangerous counterfeit airbags instead of the real thing. The photo you see here is from NHTSA's consumer website. It is taken from a videotaped test of a counterfeit air bag.

Normally, air bags are manufactured by automakers and meet crucial safety requirements. The counterfeit bags were manufactured independently and fooled buyers by closely resembling real air bags and carrying genuine-looking brand badges. Buyers were likely also enticed by low prices, with some of the air bags selling for as low as $50 to $70 each. In its warning, NHTSA suggested that anyone who has paid less than $400 for an air bag may be at risk. During testing, the counterfeit bags displayed problems ranging from non-deployment to expelling metal shrapnel.

Despite the worrying nature of this announcement, NHTSA has made it clear that it does not believe that the problem is widespread and says that it expects less than 0.1 percent of the American fleet ever to be affected by the problem. Drivers who bought their car new and have never had the air bags replaced need not worry. The real danger is from cars that have been in an accident and were repaired at an independent shop. Repair shops that are part of a dealership get their parts directly from manufacturers and would not have bought the counterfeit bags.

If you’re worried that you may have one of these in your vehicle, visit safercar.gov, which has a list of models that could possibly be affected, as well as information about the call centers established by automakers to help drivers resolve possible problems.

title: Texting and Driving: The Anti-Text Battle Continues
subTitle: Experts differ on how to get people to stop doing it, but anti-text sentiment continues to grow.
promoTitle: Texting and Driving: The Anti-Text Battle Continues
promoTeaserSmall: Experts differ on how to get people to stop doing it, but anti-text sentiment continues to grow.
promoTeaser: Experts differ on how to get people to stop doing it, but anti-text sentiment continues to grow.
metaTitle: Texting and Driving: The Anti-Text Battle Continues - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Texting and Driving: The Anti-Text Battle Continues. Learn about the latest intelligence on texting while driving at JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Despite the fact that I grew up just outside of Detroit, I was never particularly infatuated with cars. It wasn't until I headed to Washington, D.C., and began working for an environmental trade journal that I got an up close and personal look at what it takes to design an automobile. My first articles focused on efforts by legislators to make once heavily polluting cars run cleaner. When I moved back to Michigan, that became my focus as I contributed extensively to the Detroit bureaus of both the New York Times and Newsweek. I became fascinated by how the automobile impacts so many aspects of our lives and reflects our styles and preferences. Over the past two dozen years as a freelancer, I've covered the auto industry for a wide variety of publications, including Popular Mechanics, Scientific American, iVillage, Automotive News, Ad Age, Hemispheres, Technology Review, and AARP. I've also contributed pieces on air to public radio. My coverage has focused on such issues as the ways domestic automakers will respond to increasingly tough mandates for fuel-efficient cars while still designing vehicles that appeal to consumers, and my firsthand—and slightly scary—experience driving an autonomous car. But my stories are less about the vehicle than the person driving it. I'm most intrigued by the way people shape cars and cars shape those who drive them.

pageElements.text: There's no doubt that texting while driving is hazardous to the health of both drivers and others around them. That explains why thirty-nine states and the District of Columbia have enacted laws banning the practice. Now the question is: how effective have those laws been in deterring the behavior?

First, let's underline the problem, although we're sure you are already well aware that texting while driving is a very bad idea. Drivers who text while driving are six times more likely to crash than those who don't, according to a 2009 study by the University of Utah. It's difficult to determine precisely how many crashes are the direct result of texting and driving, since motorists are reluctant to admit that was the cause. But the National Safety Council found that in 2010, three percent of all crashes involved texting and driving, while 21 percent of crashes involved talking on a cell phone. Although that number may seem small, "that risk didn't exist ten years [ago], so this is a big deal," said Dave Teater, the National Safety Council's senior director of transportation initiatives.

Washington State was the first to ban texting while driving, in January 2008. The penalties for violating the law vary widely, as does the enforcement. The state of Wisconsin assesses a fine of up to $400 for the first offense, while in Kentucky a first offense carries only a $25 fine. The state of New York has issued 20,000 tickets for texting while driving, but others say the laws are often difficult to enforce. A 2010 study by the Highway Loss Data Institute found no decrease in crash risk when laws against handheld cell phones were enacted. "We don't see any evidence that texting bans are likely to make a difference in reducing crashes," said Russ Rader, a spokesman for the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.

But Russ Martin, a AAA spokesman, disagrees. "We know these laws have a significant impact on driving behavior," he says, pointing to laws mandating seatbelt use and drunk driving prohibitions as examples. He expects that the laws on texting and driving will ultimately have the same deterring effect, although he acknowledges that identifying drivers who text, then proving it in court, continues to be challenging.

Scott Kristiansen, a sergeant with the Buffalo Grove Police Department in Buffalo Grove, Illinois, knows that first hand. His state prohibits any use of electronics while driving, including texting. He says it's often difficult to see if someone is texting in a car, so he and his colleagues employ covert methods, such as having officers stand at street corners dressed as solicitors and watch people in their cars as they approach the intersection. Another tactic officers use is sitting up high in unmarked pickup trucks, from which they can look down to catch violators in their cars. He says that, as more people realize there are undercover police officers on the corners, it's likely many will change their texting behaviors.

Rader says that crash avoidance technologies being used by automakers will do far more to prevent crashes than laws banning texting while driving. One such system, forward collision warning, detects potential hazards ahead and can automatically brake if the driver doesn't react to a signal. Many car companies offer this technology under various names. Among them are Ford, Honda, Nissan, Mercedes-Benz, Toyota, and Volvo. Rader says the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety plans to reward manufacturers that have this available in its safety ratings, and indeed the IIHS already provides a searchable list of automakers and shows which cars have which of six forms of safety technology, including forward collision warning.

Martin agrees that these technologies could be helpful and says there is no single solution. "Texting while driving is so ingrained in American culture. It's not a surprise people are doing it while driving," he says. He says a multi-pronged effort, involving driver education and strong enforcement of the law, will be the best way to prevent the practice. And these days, with everyone from AT&T to the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons telling people to put the cell phone down and stop texting while driving, Martin just might get his wish.

title: 2013 Lexus CT200h
subTitle: A slickly styled, reasonably priced Lexus. Oh yeah, and it’s a hybrid.
promoTeaserSmall: A slickly styled, reasonably priced Lexus. Oh yeah, and it’s a hybrid.
promoTeaser: A slickly styled, reasonably priced Lexus. Oh yeah, and it’s a hybrid.
metaTitle: 2013 Lexus CT200h Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Lexus CT200h here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Lexus has a slew of hybrids in its fleet, and most unique of the bunch is the funky CT200h hatchback. Six grand less expensive than the next-cheapest Lexu-brid, the ES300h sedan, the CT200h blends Lexus luxury, value, and high fuel economy together in equal measure. While its overall rating of 42 miles per gallon is nowhere near that of Toyota’s iconic Prius, it represents a far more comfortable and sexy way to get your green on, with its nicely padded interior rendered in premium materials and the slew of available premium upgrades such as LED headlamps, radar-based cruise control, and an updated navigation system operated by Lexus’s innovative “Remote Touch” interface. Lexus calls the CT200h fun to drive, and for a hybrid, it kinda is, so long as your notion of “fun to drive” does not make acceleration a big priority. Even with the gas pedal pushed to the floor, getting up to highway speeds is a leisurely and noisy affair. The CT200h does have somewhat lively handling (again, for a hybrid), particularly with the tighter F-Sport package, which adds a snug suspension, sportier wheels, a mesh grille, metal pedals, and available black leather seats with white perforations. And the seats are decidedly sporty in the way they cup one’s bum. Still, the CT200h is for hybrid shoppers more interested in gaining access to Lexus-grade luxury and cachet than sportiness or hypermiling.
Fun-O-Meter: 4

Competitors:
1. Lexus HS250h
2. Audi A3 TDI
3. Toyota Prius

Cool Tech Items:
1. EV-only mode for emissions-free parking spot searches.
2. Mouse-like “Remote Touch” interface coupled with updated navigation system.

Looks:
1. F-Sport package with glossy seventeen-inch wheels, a mesh grille, and unique leather upholstery.

New for 2013:
1. Updated navigation system.
2. Padded driver armrest.
2. New Silver Lining and Ultra White colors available with F-Sport package.

title: 2013 Lexus ES
subTitle: Suddenly sexy ES gets wowza styling and new hybrid variant
promoTeaserSmall: Suddenly sexy ES gets wowza styling and new hybrid variant
promoTeaser: Suddenly sexy ES gets wowza styling and new hybrid variant
metaTitle: 2013 Lexus ES Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Lexus ES here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: While Lexus’s benign ES sedan has never been a paragon of style or excitement, the popular sedan has helped butter Lexus’s bread since the brand’s humble beginnings by putting quietness, high perceived quality, and a respectable overall luxury experience within reach for many consumers. Enter the redesigned 2013 ES, with suddenly sexy sheetmetal and a larger, scrumptious interior; together, they elevate this model from entry level status to truly desirable in its own right. Highlights of the ES’s exterior include Lexus’s new spindle grille, flanked by predatory headlamps underscored by a row of LED running lamps. The slab-like sides are complimented by side windows outlined in chrome, while ES wraparound LED taillamps dress up the rear. Inside, passengers face a new two-tiered dashboard design with an available navigation system operated by Lexus’s mouse-like Remote Touch interface, while those in back enjoy more than four inches of added legroom. The ES350’s soft-spoken V-6 engine and silky six-speed automatic transmission are largely carryovers from the previous ES350, so don’t expect much of a character change from previous ES models. More significant is the addition of the first-ever hybrid to the ES lineup called ES300h, which swaps the base V-6 for a four-cylinder engine mated to supplemental electric power, resulting in a combined EPA fuel economy rating of 40 miles per gallon.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Acura TL
2. Lincoln MKZ
3. Volvo S60

Cool Tech Items:
1. Enform app suite with Pandora, Facebook, and Yelp apps, among others.
2. Mouse-like Remote Touch control interface.
3. Available 835-watt surround sound audio system with fifteen speakers.

Looks:
1. Spindle-shaped grille and LED running lamps up front.
2. Elegant new proportions with taut sheetmetal.
3. Sexy LED-based taillamps; unique rear styling for hybrid.

New for 2013:

2. More spacious interior with environmentally friendly NuLuxe upholstery standard.
3. New hybrid ES300h model.

title: 2013 Lexus GS
subTitle: No longer a wallflower, Lexus’ beautiful GS packs full-size luxury into a mid-size package
promoTeaserSmall: No longer a wallflower, Lexus’ beautiful GS packs full-size luxury into a mid-size package
promoTeaser: No longer a wallflower, Lexus’ beautiful GS packs full-size luxury into a mid-size package

pageElements.text: Lexus’ mid-size GS sedan has never made much of a spectacle of itself in the two decades or so that it’s been around, but consider its wallflower status a thing of the past now that the all-new 2013 GS has debuted. The first Lexus model to brandish the company’s bold new design language now spreading across the lineup, the GS conveys emotion from its spindle-shaped grille all the way to its shapely tush. And that tush, along with the nose, gets even shapelier when the new-for-2013 F-Sport model is selected. More conservative folks may want to stick to Premium and Luxury models. Regardless, no GS can be considered a penalty box by any stretch of the imagination, and the Luxury model in particular is as lavish as most full-size luxury cars, complete with reclining rear seats, window shades, and a dramatic caramel-and-black color scheme that you gotta see to believe. The aforementioned F-Sport model comes with a metal and leather-trimmed cabin and boasts numerous performance enhancements, too, while the hybrid model returns for 2013 with a combined fuel economy rating of 31 mpg (versus 23 for the standard GS350). Like most Lexuses, the 2013 GS features an available infotainment system with the company’s Remote Touch interface that allows even more technology to be bundled into an already highly advanced—and highly satisfying—package.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

1. BMW 5-Series
2. Mercedes-Benz E-Class

title: 2013 Lexus GX460
subTitle: As rugged as it is elegant, the cushy GX460 gets a new suspension, but few other changes.
promoTeaserSmall: As rugged as it is elegant, the cushy GX460 gets a new suspension, but few other changes.
promoTeaser: As rugged as it is elegant, the cushy GX460 gets a new suspension, but few other changes.
metaTitle: 2013 Lexus GX460 Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Lexus GX460 here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Lexus’s luxo-ute middle-child is the big-boned GX460. Truckier than the slinky RX crossover, but not quite as grandiose as the ginormous LX570, the GX460 is nearly as comfortable on the interstate as a full-size luxury car while offering nearly as much off-road dexterity as a Land Rover LR4, not that many GX460s (or Land Rovers, for that matter) are destined to venture off-road—ever. The GX seats up to seven in leather-lined luxury, though you might want to think twice before you stick your boss in the tight third-row seat. On non-carpool days, the power third-row seat folds flat to open up some much-needed cubes of cargo space, and that space becomes even greater with the second-row seats folded nice and flat. The throaty, 4.6-liter V-8 has sufficient power, but the big news for 2013 is the installment of Lexus’ new, somewhat redundantly named Kinetic Dynamic Suspension System, designed to counteract body lean both on the road and off. That’s a good thing, considering how top-heavy the GX460 is. But style-wise, the GX remains one of the only Lexuses not to feature the company’s new form vocabulary; hence, it suddenly looks old. Still, the GX460 offers a luxo-ute experience which offers as much ruggedness as comfort, all assembled with the exquisite execution for which Lexus has become famous.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

2. Mercedes-Benz GL
3. Jeep Grand Cherokee

title: 2013 Lexus IS
subTitle: Lexus’s tidy BMW 3-Series competitor is handsome, although graying at the temples.
promoTeaserSmall: Lexus’s tidy BMW 3-Series competitor is handsome, although graying at the temples.
promoTeaser: Lexus’s tidy BMW 3-Series competitor is handsome, although graying at the temples.
metaTitle: 2013 Lexus IS Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Lexus IS here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Lexuses are not generally seen as overtly sporty automobiles, but the tidy rear-wheel-drive IS sedan is a notable exception. Like its most direct competitor, the BMW 3-Series, the IS is compact inside and out and is tuned to provide a clear connection between the driver and the road. Also like the 3-Series, the IS is available in hardtop convertible form. Both the IS sedan and the IS-C droptop are available with a choice of two engines: one with a miserly 204 horsepower and the other with a gutsier 306 horsepower, while all-wheel drive is offered on sedans as a boon to customers who happen to live where white stuff drops from the sky every now and then. Perched atop the IS range is the brutally fast, sedan-only IS-F, powered by a monstrous 414-horsepower V-8 and riding on a road-scraping suspension. A domed hood, two pairs of vertically stacked tailpipes, a rear spoiler, and aggressively bolstered front seats round out Lexus’s efforts to sportify the IS-F. If that seems interesting but excessive, Lexus makes some of the IS-F’s visual and handling excitement available in an F Sport package for regular IS sedans and convertibles. All that said, the IS has been around for a long time, and next to its competitors, including the redesigned BMW 3-Series and the all-new Cadillac ATS, the 2013 IS feels, well, old. A redesigned IS is expected in 2013 as a 2014 model, but in the meantime, this is as sporty as it gets at the Lexus store.
Fun-O-Meter: 7 (IS); 9 (IS-F)

Competitors:
1. BMW 3-Series
2. Mercedes-Benz C-Class
3. Cadillac ATS

Cool Tech Items:

2. Burly V-8 in IS-F is a masterpiece.

title: 2012 Lexus LFA
subTitle: An enigmatic, exotic, and exceedingly expensive exception to Lexus’ every rule
promoTeaserSmall: An enigmatic, exotic, and exceedingly expensive exception to Lexus’ every rule
promoTeaser: An enigmatic, exotic, and exceedingly expensive exception to Lexus’ every rule
metaTitle: 2012 Lexus LFA Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2012 Lexus LFA here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: We’re not sure what Lexus product planners were smoking when they came up with the idea to take on Ferrari with its limited-production, 553-horsepower LFA supercar, but we sort of hope they find some more (and share it with some other brands while they’re at it). A true feast for the eyes, the LFA’s coupe-gone-wild styling is highlighted by massive air ducts and grilles all over the car, exquisite details like arrow-themed headlamps and spear-like boomerang-shaped taillamps, and a trio of exhaust pipes in the middle of the rear bumper. But the LFA’s wild styling only hints at the unbelievable experience that awaits any one lucky enough to slip behind the wheel on a long stretch of open road. The purpose-built V-10 rivals any Italian supercar in its thrust and song, while the steering serves up road feel as if on a silver platter. Two racing-style seats are all that fit in the LFA’s sexalicious interior and reconfigurable LCD gauges are truly state-of-the-art. Certainly, we’ll see that technology pop up on other Lexus models in the future, hopefully on vehicles less costly than the LFA, which Lexus brazenly slapped with a base price of $375K. For that coin, exclusivity also comes standard: production has been capped at 500 for the world, all sold as 2012 models. So why is this car listed in a 2013 buyer’s guide? At the time of this writing, Lexus said that a few may still be available.
Fun-O-Meter: 12

Competitors:
1. Ferrari 12 Berlinetta
2. Porsche 911 GT2
3. Aston Martin Vanquish

Cool Tech Items:
1. Everything.

Looks:
1. Everything.

title: 2013 Lexus LX570
subTitle: Lexus’s big bruiser is bolder on the outside, but still nice and soft on the inside.
promoTeaserSmall: Lexus’s big bruiser is bolder on the outside, but still nice and soft on the inside.

metaTitle: 2013 Lexus LX570 Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
