pageElements.text: At a time when big, corpulent SUVs have been disappearing like so many tyrannosauruses after the asteroid struck, Lexus remains doubled-down in the large lux-u-vee market with the sufficiently cushy GX460 and then this monster, the LX570. Is Lexus out of touch? If you have to ask, you’re obviously not among the “one-percenters” at whom the LX570 is aimed. Compared to Toyota’s (slightly) cheaper Land Cruiser, with which the LX570 shares many of its dirty parts, the LX570 gains distinction primarily because of its elegant Lexus styling (complete with Lexus’s new spindle grille and LED taillamps) and fancy-schmancy interior, thus allowing it to compete with high-profile status symbols such as Cadillac’s blingy Escalade and Land Rover’s legendary Range Rover. Of course, a truck this massive requires a huge engine with huge power, which, not surprisingly, comes at a cost in the form of abysmal fuel economy. Then again, that particular point tends to be more of a concern for the ninety-nine-percenters; this vehicle’s target market will be much more interested in the new Parchment leather option, spacious seven-passenger seating, and the refreshed interior with mahogany wood trim and black chrome accents. They may not even care about the pittance of cargo space behind the third-row seat. For luxury SUV buyers for whom decadence and Armageddon-grade capability are important, Lexus has a ride for you.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

3. Land Rover Range Rover

title: 2013 Lexus RX350/RX450h
subTitle: Popularity has never looked so good: Lexus gives its best-selling RX crossover a facelift
promoTeaserSmall: Popularity has never looked so good: Lexus gives its best-selling RX crossover a facelift
promoTeaser: Popularity has never looked so good: Lexus gives its best-selling RX crossover a facelift
metaTitle: 2013 Lexus RX350/RX450h Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Lexus RX350/RX450h here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Luxury crossovers have been all the rage for years now, and none has been found in as many manicured driveways and portes cochères as Lexus’ RX. As a crossover and not a trucky SUV, and with only two rows of seats and not three (like Lexus’s other two luxury utes), the RX is spacious but not excessive, capable but not corpulent, comfortable but not conspicuously consumptive. In other words, for most moderately well-to-do households with a kid or two and a dog, it is just right. Now in the middle of its product cycle, Lexus has seen fit to give its popular RX a thorough face-lift, blessing the mug with the company’s new hourglass-shaped grille and LED daytime running lamp spears, complimented by new taillamps and tailgate details. The interior is slightly upgraded with some new color and trim choices and added technology such as Bluetooth connectivity and Lexus’s new Enform suite of in-car apps, including Pandora, Bing, Facebook, and more. With driving dynamics about as benign as your great aunt Matilda, the RX has never been too exciting to drive, though a new-for-2013 F-Sport model livens things up with its tightened suspension and paddle-shifted eight-speed transmission. And of course, the hybrid RX model (which, as Lexus proudly reminds us, was the industry’s first hybrid SUV) receives the same styling and interior enhancements as the standard model with considerably better fuel economy (30 mpg versus 21 mpg combined), albeit at a steep $6,600 premium. At least a laundry list of safety features come standard on all, most notably ten air bags, including knee airbags for the driver and front passenger.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

3. Lincoln MKX

title: 2013 Toyota FJ Cruiser
subTitle: The most fun you can have in a Toyota.
promoTeaserSmall: The most fun you can have in a Toyota.
promoTeaser: The most fun you can have in a Toyota.
metaTitle: 2013 Toyota FJ Cruiser Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Toyota FJ Cruiser here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: If you called your mother and told her you bought a new Toyota, she’d no doubt be pleased. “Oh, how responsible you’ve become,” she’d say. “You’re all grown up!” Now imagine her face when you pull up in an FJ Cruiser. More Hummer than Camry, the FJ Cruiser features cartoonish, Tonka toy (Tonka Toyota?) styling, making it something of a life-sized version of the knobby-tired toy trucks you may have played with in the sandbox as a youngster. Its most direct competitor is the Jeep Wrangler, to give you an idea of the FJ’s overall attitude, and with its locking rear differential, awesome ground clearance, and torquey, 260-horsepower V-6, the FJ is suitably fantastic off-road. (Side note: why Toyota never made a topless version of the FJ is simply beyond us.) On-road, it’s somewhat less at home, with horrendous blind spots, bump-a-long ride quality, and a slim, wide windshield that requires three wipers to clear. For an SUV, it also isn’t the most practical, thanks to its rear-hinged rear doors and modicum of cargo space. And don’t get us started on its fuel economy. That said, even though the FJ Cruiser is getting up there in years, we still love the way it looks. And best of all, it’s still an actual Toyota, which means that Mom will still approve.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. Jeep Wrangler
2. Toyota 4Runner
3. Land Rover LR4

Cool Tech Items:
1. Standard locking rear differential for serious off-roaders.

Looks:
1. Cement gray color for Trail Teams Special Edition with matching interior.
2. Timeless, Tonka toy styling sets it apart.
3. Rear-hinged doors.

New for 2013:
1. New content for Trail Teams Special Edition.
2. Daytime running lamps.
3. Silver Fresco paint replaced by Magma.

title: 2013 Toyota Sequioa
subTitle: If you think bigger is better, Toyota’s got a tree—er, truck—for you
promoTeaserSmall: If you think bigger is better, Toyota’s got a tree—er, truck—for you
promoTeaser: If you think bigger is better, Toyota’s got a tree—er, truck—for you
metaTitle: 2013 Toyota Sequioa Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Toyota Sequioa here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: It’s a little ironic that the huge, gas-swillin’, eight-passenger Toyota Sequoia shares its name with an endangered species of redwood tree, considering that saving trees is generally not the highest priority of most gargant-u-vee customers. Less surprising is that this sport-utility expression of Toyota’s full-sized, San Antonio-built Tundra pickup, is more than pleasant to drive. The massive interior offers plenty of room to spread out, with a max capacity of eight hearty souls. Only one engine, a 381-horsepower V-8, does the tugging, channeling its power through a six-speed automatic, making the towing of a large travel trailer or boat an easy affair. For 2013, not much has been changed or added except for the optional navigation system (which now features Toyota’s new EnTune apps) and a new Blu-ray player for rear-seat entertainment system. Three trim levels remain on the menu: SR5, Limited, and Platinum, the latter the only Toyota other than the pish-posh Land Cruiser to cross the $60K mark. That’s a chunk of change to be sure, but particularly in its lower grades, the Sequoia offers a whole lot of truck for the money, with proven reliability to boot.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

title: 2013 Mazda 6
subTitle: The 2013 Mazda 6 is a sportier alternative to mainstream sedans.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Mazda 6
promoTeaser: 2013 Mazda 6
metaTitle: 2013 Mazda 6--Buyer's Guide--Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Mazda 6 here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The Mazda 6 has always been an excellent choice if you’re the type of person who cringes when you see another person wearing the same dress as you at a party. With the Japanese mid-size sedan, you won’t see yourself coming and going on the road as you will with some of the domestic competition. Mazda is in something of a holding pattern with the Mazda 6 at this point, since a fully redesigned model is coming out for 2014. In the meantime, there are no significant changes to the Mazda 6. The current-generation sedan has a striking presence, with a long hood and flared front fenders. Mazda pitches it as "sexy, yet sensible." The base model is nicely equipped with standard air conditioning, power accessories, cruise control, and a stereo system with six speakers. The base Mazda 6 is equipped with a 170-horsepower 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine linked to a six-speed manual transmission. The top-of-the-line model gets a 272-horsepower 3.7-liter V-6 engine linked to a six-speed automatic transmission. There are numerous options, including a rear spoiler, remote engine start on automatic-transmission models, pearl exterior paint, and a power moonroof. A $1,785 technology package bundles several items, including LED rear lights, heated side mirrors, and a power front passenger’s seat. On the downside, there is no hybrid option as there is with some of the competition.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Hyundai Sonata
2. Nissan Altima
3. Toyota Camry
4. Honda Accord
5. Ford Fusion

Cool Tech:
1. Optional blind-spot monitoring system.

title: 2013 Mazda CX-5
subTitle: The 2013 Mazda CX-5 is a compact SUV for style-conscious buyers who always wanted a Mazda Miata but need the space to haul Little Leaguers.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Mazda CX-5
promoTeaser: 2013 Mazda CX-5
metaTitle: 2013 Mazda CX-5--Buyer's Guide--Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Mazda CX-5 here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Mazda CX-5 is a new small SUV that replaces the Mazda Tribute and slots in at the bottom of Mazda’s SUV lineup. The five-passenger CX-5 has lots to recommend it. It’s one of the few small SUVs to offer a manual transmission, but buyers can opt for the six-speed manual transmission or six-speed automatic transmission. It also delivers better gas mileage than many of its competitors, including the Honda CR-V, Toyota RAV4, and Ford Escape. The CX-5 with the 155-horsepower 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine and six-speed manual delivers 26 mpg in the city and 35 mpg on the highway, according to the EPA. The CX-5 uses Mazda’s new Skyactiv Technology that reduces fuel consumption and emissions without compromising driving performance. But the small Japanese SUV is far from being just a sensible pair of shoes. The shapely CX-5 is for style-conscious buyers who like Jimmy Choo and Jason Wu. There is a full complement of standard safety features, including six air bags, antilock brakes, stability control, and traction control. Options include a blind spot monitoring system and adaptive front headlights. The CX-5 doesn’t break much new ground in the cabin, but it is one of the most affordable small SUVs on the market. The base 2013 CX-5 Sport starts at $21,490, including a $795 destination charge, making it less expensive than the CR-V, RAV4, and Escape.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Honda CR-V
2. Ford Escape
3. Toyota RAV4

Cool Tech:
1. Blind-spot monitoring system is unusual in this segment.

New for 2013:
1. All new.

title: 2013 Mazda MX-5 Miata
subTitle: The long-standing Mazda MX-5 Miata is a sports car for purists.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Mazda MX-5 Miata
promoTeaser: 2013 Mazda MX-5 Miata
metaTitle: 2013 Mazda MX-5 Miata--Buyer's Guide--Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Mazda MX-5 Miata here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The rear-wheel-drive Mazda MX-5 Miata – which has been around for more than twenty years – stands out as one of the most spirited and affordable sports cars on the market. It charms with its classic roadster styling and engaging performance. It marks the new model year with a restyled front end. The single downfall in the MX-5 Miata is space. Taller drivers may feel cramped with the top up and the narrow two-seat cabin may leave some feeling slightly claustrophobic. The trunk is Lilliputian. The base car comes with a manual-folding soft top; a power-retractable hard top is optional. The power top is the way to go if you live in a cold-weather state. It goes without saying that the MX-5 Miata is a blast to drive, even though the engine puts out a relatively modest amount of power. A 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine delivers 158 horsepower when mated with the optional six-speed automatic transmission. When equipped with the five- or six-speed manual transmission, it produces 167 horsepower. Models with the five-speed manual transmission deliver 22 mpg in city driving and 28 mpg on the highway, according to the EPA. Standard features include air conditioning, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, and cloth upholstery. Expect to pay in the neighborhood of around $25,000 for a base model. For many households, this means that the little roadster is an excellent choice for a second car.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Audi TT
2. Mini Cooper Roadster
3. Porsche Boxster
4. Volkwagen Eos

Cool Tech:
1. Nothing noteworthy; pretty old school.

New for 2013:
1. Restyled front end.
2. Base Sport trim gains fog lights.
3. Club model replaces Touring Trim.

pageElements.text: Not many people can say they learned to drive a manual-transmission car in one of the world’s most beautiful and exotic locales—but I can. I was twenty-three years old and had only gotten my driver’s license the previous year, after putting it off on the grounds that I was a hippie and had no car anyway.

In the early 1980s, I found myself in France, where cars with stick shifts were the rule rather than the exception. Still: no car, no problem. But then came the trip where I hitchhiked with a non-driving friend from northeast France down to Nice and got on a ferry to a place where a car was indispensable: the island of Corsica.

If you’ve never thought much about the island of Corsica except a vague recollection that Napoleon was from there, you’ve missed something in life. A.k.a. “the scented isle,” Corsica is a jewel. It lolls in the Mediterranean, south of France—to which it belongs—just north of Sardinia and west of Sicily.

I had phoned ahead in this pre-e-mail time and reserved an automatic-transmission car from the Hertz agency in Bastia, on the island’s northern tip. We had in mind spending three days driving all the way around the entire island near the shore. You can pretty much do that the whole way on the small routes nationales, and I recommend it.

Just as an interesting bit of trivia, there were serious issues with terrorist activity at the time: a liberation movement to cut Corsica loose from France was in full swing, bombings at tourist resorts around the island were happening, that sort of thing.

Full of American-tourist confidence, I walked in to the Hertz office, only to be told that there were no cars available with automatic transmissions. Indeed, the rental agent seemed not to understand that such a car existed. I explained my ignorance of stick-shift usage, and she rolled her eyes, then came out from behind the desk, swinging a car key, and invited me to follow her.

Out on the street stood a Citroen LNA. I eyed it warily. She bundled me into it, sat in the passenger’s seat, and proceeded to talk me through the process of driving it. Luckily I had been in France long enough to understand the language, but there was a definite mechanical intelligence barrier. After a few turns around the block, somehow she satisfied herself that I had the basic idea—I don’t know how, since I stalled every time I lifted my clumsy left foot off the clutch. She washed her hands of me and returned to the office, and the car was ours for the weekend.
It seemed to take nine hours to get out of Bastia. Old men were coming out of cafes to point and stare.

I will never, ever forget the feeling of driving that car out of town at rush hour on a Friday afternoon. I stalled, gunned the engine, and made that minicar dance like water on a hot griddle, over and over again. It seemed to take nine hours to get out of Bastia. Old men were coming out of cafes to point and stare. Teens on motorbikes roared past, making rude remarks such as “Ouais, elle sait meme pas conduire sa bagnole, eh!” (she doesn’t even know how to drive her car). Meanwhile, on every corner stood an armed police officer, placed there to strike fear in the hearts of bombers, I guess, but they weren’t pulling off the tough act so well, since they were doubled over laughing at me.

Getting out into the countryside had its own challenges. It was essential to sound the car horn when going around one of the many blind curves, since there might be a car coming the other way. More important, there might be sheep. And there often were—hundreds of them, milling around in the middle of the road. They usually looked up at our approaching car with mild indifference, but eventually they would move.

Over the course of the weekend, I learned a lot about driving. On stretches of unpopulated road between villages, I was able to work out the gentle balance of lifting the left foot as I depressed the right, moving up through the gears with increasing confidence. I’m not saying I became a great stick-shift driver, but before long I reached the point of comfort, and then of unconscious competence.

I couldn’t wait to get back to the Hertz office and triumphantly hand the keys to the rental clerk, proclaiming success. Unfortunately, the office was closed on Monday afternoons, so my great adventure ended with the anticlimax of dropping the keys through a slot. In my heart, though, I knew I had won. Plus, I liked it. My first new car, purchased four years later, had a manual transmission.

images.caption: Bastia, at Corsica's northern tip, where I picked up the car.

pageElements.text:
Is this a necessary skill?

My friend Julie has always driven manual-transmission Subarus. Years ago, she was far out in the country, late at night, with a passenger who didn’t know how to drive a stick shift. A rabbit ran out in front of her car, and she couldn’t avoid it, and it was killed. She was so distraught that she couldn’t continue driving. The passenger couldn’t drive a stick, so there they sat half the night until Julie was calm enough to drive again. It occurred to me: what if there had been some other kind of emergency? Thinking about that should convince anyone to acquire this essential driving skill. Plus, it’s fun once you get the hang of it!

I’ll tell you one thing: my own kids are going to learn how to drive a stick shift--but definitely from a qualified instructor, not the way I did. In fact, if they could arrange to do hardly any of the crazy things I did at their age, that would be great.

Feedback wanted!

What about you? Do you know how to drive a manual-transmission car? Have you always wanted to? Have you tried and given up? We want to hear all the details. Please Comment below.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

relatedArticles.title: How I Learned to Drive a Stick Shift

pageElements.text: The first time I drove a stick was on Christmas Day, the winter after I got my driver’s license. I had decided that I wanted to learn how to drive a manual, probably because I wanted an excuse to drive my parents’ cars, which were much nicer than mine. My first session was fine, but not great. I was in my mom’s Saab 9-5, and I didn’t make it out of the parking lot, but I also didn’t destroy the car’s transmission.

A few days later, I tried again in my dad’s Subaru WRX. He had warned me that this transmission would be more difficult than the Saab’s, but I am rarely put off by warnings of that type. He was right, of course, and after spending an hour or so failing to get the car in gear while it bucked wildly around the parking lot, we gave up (him because he was afraid I was breaking his car, and me because I was crying a lot). I still regard that day as a resounding failure, but I did get the best piece of advice I’ve ever gotten about driving a manual when my father suggested I should let out the clutch and press on the gas simultaneously, “like two ships passing in the night.” I still think about that.

I got back behind the wheel of the Saab a few weeks later, but gave up for good when I got stuck on a hill and the car started leaking acrid-smelling smoke. After that, I always maintained that I could drive a stick if I absolutely had to, like if someone had a gun to my head and said they would let me live if I could shift to fifth gear and back. Luckily,  I never had to find out if I was right (I probably wasn’t).

Four years later while home for vacation I got another set of lessons from my mom, this time in her Saturn Astra. We drove around town and I only stalled at one light (though I stalled at that light at least eight times before I finally got the thing to start.) Then one day, my mom took my car to work and left me with the Astra, forcing me to either drive it or stay home all day, which is what she should have done all along, really, because that’s what finally did the trick.

contributors.displayName: Jean Jennings, President and Editor in Chief
contributors.bio:
Jean Jennings has been writing about cars and the car business for more than thirty years. She learned about cars at the kitchen table from her father Robert, the late editor of Automotive News. At the age of eighteen, she bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, Jennings went to Chrysler’s test track where she worked as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, she was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine when she was laid off her Chrysler job, and in 1985 she left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr., as its first executive editor. She became Editor-in-Chief in 2000 and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

Jennings has won awards for her feature writing, for her car reviews, and for her monthly Automobile Magazine column “Vile Gossip.” She was the recipient of the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism. Jennings has the unique experience, sensibility, and personality to connect with women and to give them voice in the male-dominated automotive space. She was the subject of a Susan Orlean profile in the New Yorker, has appeared on numerous television news shows, has been on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno, and was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000.

She is currently a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News.

Jennings lives in the Michigan countryside with her husband, Tim, and the entire food chain.

pageElements.text: Highest among the many reasons I love cars are (1) the amazing places they have taken me, and (2) the great characters I’ve met along the way. The highlight of my 2012 was traveling to Austin, Texas, last spring to hang out with the heavily tattooed VooDoo Dolls car club at the Lonestar Rod & Kustom Roundup, a two-day car show and music festival sponsored by Austin’s famous Continental Club.

I don’t have tattoos, not that I haven’t had random thoughts over the years about what I would have inked on an arm if the spirit moved me. “Tim Is Gone,” my husband, Tim, has suggested. I find that hilarious.

But I’ve had old cars and worked on them at a time when young girls didn’t, and when the guys I hung out with didn’t, either. Not that there weren’t any. There were plenty. It’s just that, back then, I didn’t know where the other girls were, you know?

I saw the Dolls a year ago on a documentary celebrating Chevrolet’s centennial, talking about their all-girls car club and their love of cars. How cool! And it didn’t hurt that they were such characters, with their humorous neon green logo, their tattoos, and their bigger-than-life personalities shining through the screen. 
Here are the girls I wish I’d known when I was growing up:

—Peggy Ellis, 37, is one of Austin’s more interesting registered dental assistants when you consider the one-and-three-quarter-inch ear plugs stretching her lobes nearly to her shoulders and the riotous canvas of inked images poking out of her tank top and snaking down her legs below denim cutoffs. They are old school charming, and she proudly cites the famous artists who’ve worked on her. As far as I can tell, there’s not a lot of room left.

Peggy founded the VooDoo Dolls CC in 2006 with four friends, of whom two (Marcee Ribeiro and Jane Johnson) are still active members. 
“The club was started in March 2006 after we’d all met and gone to car events together,” Peggy recounts. “We decided we were tired of tagging along with the guys, so we started a car club of our own. Our motto has always been, “We like grease on more than just our pillowcases.” That cracks her up.

“We owe a lot to the clubs that came before us. The BelleFlowers. The Pink Slips. The Pedal Pushers. We spent five days saying no one wanted to be wearing pink. Mike Adair, a tattoo artist, drew our logo.
“With thanks to the club, we have all become eager to learn our way around our cars as well as other cars,” she says. “We all have and do work on the cars that we own.”

—Marcee Ribeiro, 37, has jet black hair, bright red lips, and short shorts and alternates between cowgirl and motorcycle boots. She owns a 1958 Chevy Bel Air that is photo-realistically tattooed on her right thigh, just below another tattoo, of her mother. “This is Mary L., my mom,” she tells me. “She was a special ed teacher. And this is her car. My mom hated my tattoos, but she would have liked this one.

“She took her driving test in a 1958 Bel Air, and she told my dad about it. My dad builds cars, and he found a 1958 Bel Air in a pasture one night. He stopped and asked the farmer how much, the farmer told him $150, and my dad paid him and went back the next day. That’s when he saw that the whole front end was wrecked. But he didn’t care, because my mom wanted it.

“It took him seven or eight years to rebuild it to show condition. My mom was so proud of it. They let me drive it to prom, and I got a flat tire. I jacked it up on the body instead of the frame. My dad took the keys and told me I could never drive it again. When my mom passed, he gave it to me. He helps me work on it. Recently, he was doing a tuneup and asked me if I had the owner’s manual. ‘I need to set the firing order [of the spark plugs],’ he said. ‘Well, Daddy, I wrote that down from last time,’ I told him. ‘You wrote it down? You have it?’ ‘Yeah, Daddy, I kept it.’ ‘Well, goddamn!’ he said.

“What I really want is one of those Trophy Queen purses, but it costs $350, and I really need a new motor. My daddy isn’t normally sweet, but he said, ‘Sit down, honey. Now sweetie, there’s nothing more I can do. That motor is shot.’ I feel like I’ve been working on that car all my life,” she sighs. “Still, the more you know, the easier you find out it is. Hell, baking is harder than working on cars.”

—Jane Johnson, 28, another of the VooDoo Dolls co-founders, works on the Whole Foods website at its Austin headquarters. Her tattoos are an altogether different style, in the manner of Mexican candle saints, only with an automotive theme. Look closely, and you’ll see butterflies filled with pistons and wrenches. Our Lady of Guadalupe is standing piously amid spark plugs and burning rubber on Jane’s right outer thigh. "Nothing does more for my spirit than the Dolls,” says Jane.

—Vanessa Calovich, 29, is a Kansas farm girl who has been a member of the Dolls since she was twenty-four, is the acknowledged mechanic of the group, and has a tattoo of Robert Mitchum’s head on her left thigh. Robert Mitchum as he appeared in the 1958 movie Thunder Road, to be exact.

“Excuse me,” I ask her. “Is that Robert Mitchum tattooed on your thigh?”
She says, “Yeah, dude, this is gonna be my thigh of dead men I’d like to meet.”

“Who else is gonna be on it?” I ask.
“Steve McQueen, Paul Newman, and Gene Wilder,” she replies.
“Gene Wilder?!?” we all shout at once and burst out laughing. Especially because Gene Wilder is not even dead yet.
“Dude,” she answers, with great seriousness. “Gene Wilder’s hot!”
—Nicole Soumbeniotis, 35, has been a member since 2008.

“Let me spell that for you.” She spells her name twice, and then she writes it down. I can proudly say that I just typed it from memory. Nicole has a car, but it currently resides in another state, which doesn’t slow her down. She’s hanging with the girls, wearing full lime green on black VooDoo Dolls regalia. (You know how JKC loves that lime green.)

—Nikki Lange, 40, joined in 2010. She’s the newest and oldest member of the Dolls. She works for the city of Austin, but don’t let that give you the wrong idea about her. “San Diego is my hometown. I moved to Austin in 2006, following my ex-husband. He lost me, the dog, the house, and the hot rod.

“Before I got divorced, all my tats were on my upper arms. My favorite tattoo is ‘Cruisin’ Is Not a Crime.’ I wanted to do that first, but it was so boyish, I did a heart on my back instead. I wanted to place ‘Cruisin’ Is Not a Crime’ very carefully where people couldn’t see it unless I wanted them to. So it’s on the inside of my left upper arm. It’s my favorite tattoo, and I placed it so I could see it in my rear-view mirror.

“After the divorce, I thought, is the tattoo culture part of before, or is this going to be me on my own? I knew the girls and they were my support. My tattoos are a sign of my independence, and I was way late to the scene. They don’t mean anything deep. I just like them.”

Being a member of the Dolls also gave Lange a reason to keep her hot rod truck. “I learned how to work on my truck using Auto Mechanics for Dummies. I take a photo of everything, how it looks before I take it out.”

The Dolls were up all night Wednesday baking desserts (for 500!) for the traditional Thursday night Meatheads car club barbecue to welcome the hot rodders pouring into town for the Lonestar Roundup. “We took the baked goods over in a new car because we didn’t want them to taste like gas,” said Peggy. And then they partied all night Thursday. Pure adrenaline, copious amounts of Lone Star beer, and dancing to the local Texas swing and country music like the LeRoi Brothers blasting from the stage kept them going all day Friday. There were tattoo artist friends and hot rod legends for Peggy to visit. There were minibike races in the rodeo ring for Vanessa to flag off, and a display of the coveted Trophy Queen purses in the surprisingly jammed barn of cool Fifties-era clothing for Marcee and Nikki to cruise.

The VooDoo Dolls turned in early and came back for more on Saturday, gearing up for their heroine Wanda Jackson, the Queen of Rockabilly, to hit the stage late afternoon. Then they packed up the circus and prepared to move it to town, with parties at Austin’s numerous speed shops and a killer evening of cruising Congress Avenue.

“Sunday, we have Chickenshit Bingo with Dale Watson at Ginny’s Little Longhorn,” said Marcy. “Everyone sits around waiting for the chicken to shit and hoping it shits on their number, while Dale Watson is playing and singing about Lone Star beer.”

Sadly, I was going to have to miss that. Devastated, I gathered with them on Saturday night for one last Lone Star to talk about the tattoos, the cars, and mostly the bond these women have for each other.
Nicole Soumbeniotis: “I love everything about the club.”
Jane Johnson: “Nothing does more for my spirit than the Dolls.”
Peggy Ellis: “Everything is loud and fast and go-go-go.”
Marcee Ribeiro: “It’s family.”
Nikki Lange: “It’s just badass. It’s my power suit.”

pageElements.text: If you’ve gotten behind the wheel of a Ford Focus recently, you may have noticed that the windshield wipers aren’t your grandfather’s squeegees. Or you might not have noticed, since they’re not exactly the first things you look at in a new car.

But notice them or not, good wipers are crucial to your safety in poor weather conditions, and the Focus has innovative ones. Instead of the long, bulky motor that typically operates the two windshield wipers and runs the length of a car’s hood, the Focus employs two small, side-mounted motors. Not only do they weigh less and take up less space, they also improve the functionality of the wipers and allow them to operate independently.

The independent movements allow the blades to correct themselves if they become cockeyed during cleaning or operation. It also allows their resting positions to change periodically to prevent a problem called permanent set, a result of the hardening of rubber over time that can significantly decrease the life of a set of wiper blades.
As a bonus, developer Robert Bosch LLC says the smaller, lighter motors can lead to modestly reduced emissions and fuel consumption.

The direct drive windshield wipers were provided by Robert Bosch LLC for the Focus starting with the 2012 model, and similar technology from supplier Valeo is on Ford’s all-new 2013 Escape, Fusion, and C-Max. Best of all, the futuristic wipers come standard on all four models.

metaDescription: A Postmodern Pleyel Piano by Peugeot: JeanKnowsCars.com shows you a postmodern piano designed for the Paris Auto Show by French automaker Peugeot with French piano maker Pleyel.

contributors.bio:
Robert Cumberford is a designer who became a writer by accident. His race report on the 12 Hours of Sebring was published when he was an eighteen-year-old Art Center student in 1954. Subsequently he has published thousands of articles on cars and airplanes, in American, Asian, English, European, and South American magazines. He contributed to several books, including the entire text of the well-reviewed Auto Legends, now available in five translated editions -- French, German, Spanish, Italian, and Polish in addition to the original English version. In 1985, Automobile Magazine founder David E. Davis, Jr., invited him to be one of two executive editors when Automobile was in the planning stages. Cumberford demurred, saying he knew nothing about magazine production and claims he still doesn’t, except that it’s important to meet deadlines. He contributed features from the beginning and began his popular “By Design” column in the sixth issue, September 1986.

In car design, Cumberford was even more a youthful prodigy. He sketched the body for the first car ever built to his designs when he was a fifteen-year-old Los Angeles high-school student. That car, the Parkinson Jaguar Special, is still active in historic racing sixty years after it was created. Hired directly by General Motors’ legendary Vice President of Design, Harley J. Earl, Cumberford became a professional car designer at nineteen. Leaving Detroit, he returned to California to attend UCLA to study philosophy. He rejoined the automotive world in the early 1960s and has continued to create new automotive shapes since then, always as an independent design consultant. He has lived and worked in six of the fifty United States and in France, Mexico, and Switzerland. The range of his design projects includes both racing and touring cars, trucks, aircraft, boats, hovercraft, and even ecological architecture.

He is known worldwide for strong opinions but is well-respected in the design world because it is known that he is always completely honest in his views, with no agenda other than respect for good design and good designers. “There’s no ad hominem,” he says, “I judge the design, not the designers. There are designers I really like personally who’ve been credited with designs I heartily dislike -- for reasons I always state very clearly -- and designs I love done by people with whom I have absolutely no affinity. Except that we both like their work.”

pageElements.text: There is undoubted romance to cars, never better expressed than by Ned Jordan’s classic advertisement for his Twenties Playboy roadster saying “Somewhere west of Laramie there’s a bronco-busting, steer-roping girl…” There’s romance to pianos, too, beautifully explained in Thad Carhart’s The Piano Shop on the Left Bank, subtitled “Discovering a Forgotten Passion in a Paris Atelier.”

Despite that similarity, if you try to draw a link between automobiles and pianos — or vehicles and any musical instrument, for that matter — most people cannot see any possible connection. In fact, there have been quite a few surprising associations, beginning in the nineteenth century and continuing to the very latest international motor show, the Mondial de l’Automobile in Paris this month. Along with an exotic concept car, Peugeot showed a prototype piano conceived with the aid of the venerable piano maker Maison Pleyel, which, like Peugeot itself, was founded more than 200 years ago. Pleyel is the oldest piano maker in the world, and although it is not as well known as Baldwin, Bechstein, Bosendorfer, or Steinway and Sons, it is highly respected by musicians everywhere.

The Steinway-Daimler Connection

The first automobile-piano connection was between the Steinway piano company and Gottlieb Daimler. In 1888, when the American piano manufacturer William Steinway was traveling in Europe, he heard of Daimler’s motorized quadricycle. Intrigued, he went to Cannstatt, a district in Stuttgart, Germany, to experience the vehicle for himself. He was impressed enough by his “cross country” ride that he undertook a license to build Daimler’s engines, used first for boats and streetcars and then for trucks. That led to the New York City manufacture under license of a few Mercedes-Benz cars in 1905, a venture stopped by a factory fire in 1907.

The Pleyel-Chopin Connection

Ignaz Pleyel, a student of Joseph Haydn and, in his own right, an accomplished musician and composer (forty-one symphonies, hundreds of string quartets and quintets), established his piano works in 1807 as an adjunct to his musical publishing house, Maison Pleyel. His purpose was to create instruments that enhanced the capabilities of musicians, including the virtuoso Chopin. Pleyel was a constant innovator and the first to make pianos with metal frames, as opposed to the all-wood structures used previously. That history of creation and change was one of the inspirations for the collaboration of the firm he founded with today’s Peugeot Design Lab, an ancillary part of the car company’s design operation dedicated to work for clients outside the automotive group.

2005: BMW 507 Designer Tries Hand at Steinway Type A

In recent years, there have been other exercises wherein car designers have tackled piano design. For the 125th anniversary of the Steinway’s Hamburg, Germany, operation in 2005, Albrecht, Count Goertz, a German-born American industrial designer best known for his masterpiece BMW 507 sports car, and for having imagined the Datsun 240Z, a great commercial success, was commissioned to create a baby grand piano. It was classical in appearance and very beautiful, with different textures and shades of black finish, but it broke no new technical ground. As the model A-188, it is available today at an unchanged price, $77,400.

2007: Porsche Design's Bosendorfer Grand Piano

Two years later, F.A. Porsche Design proposed another classically shaped grand piano for German piano maker Bosendorfer, this time with some functional changes from the concert grand piano pattern established in 1875 by Henry Englehard Steinway. The lid was made of a honeycomb-core material, lightweight but stiff enough to reflect sounds into the concert hall. The price is $120,000, about the same as a well-equipped Porsche 911 Carrera coupe, and it looks to weigh about the same as well.

2009: Audi Design's Bauhaus-Inspired Bosendorfer

Then, in 2009, Audi Design stylists did another Bosendorfer, this time taking the backboard almost all the way to the floor. The form was clearly inspired by Bauhaus concepts from the 1920s, with carefully delineated discrete shapes for each distinct component of the whole, including the keyboard and its cover, the pedal lyre in aluminum, and the pedals themselves. Apart from the fact that the lid is hinged below the upper perimeter of the piano, there are few changes from the classical form. This piano is commercially available for about $140,000 — again, comparable to the prices of top Audi car models.

2012: Peugeot and Pleyel Advance the Art

But, as shown in the photos above, none of the efforts in the time since William Steinway went into the car business have so completely altered the idea of what a grand piano should be as the Peugeot-Pleyel project. True to Ignaz Pleyel’s open mind in moving piano design forward, the new design incorporates advanced materials — carbon-fiber-reinforced plastics, principally — with a radical repositioning and reproportioning of the technical elements of the piano. The entire sound-producing set of strings has been lowered so that it is on a level with the keyboard. Thus, the pianist’s hands can be seen by the audience, and the artist himself or herself benefits from a better sound experience.

Instead of three legs, the piano is supported by a single pedestal formed of an aerodynamically styled carbon fiber molding. To avoid any resonance of the hollow cantilever, it is filled with foam to make it acoustically inert. The soundboard and main body are made of wood according to traditional practice, giving a rich sound available with no other material. The lid is carbon fiber, but it does not require a prop to hold it open. Instead, gas struts and a clever mechanical linkage allow the lid to be opened and positioned by one hand.

Like the other three contemporary car-designer pianos, the Pleyel by Peugeot Design Lab is available for purchase. Priced at €165,000 (about $205,000), it is a science-fiction-like transformation of a well-known object. It maintains all the virtues of its ancestors while bringing a true advance in presenting the performer’s hands to concert goers for the first time since the concert grand was conceived.

title: The Car Seat Years
promoTeaserSmall: A mom looks back as her son reaches the size where he no longer needs a car seat or booster.
promoTeaser: A mom looks back as her son reaches the size where he no longer needs a car seat or booster.
metaTitle: Car Seat Years - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Read as Jean Jenning's reminiscences about the car seat years after her son reaches the size where he no longer needs a car seat or booster, only on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I’m a jazz aficionado, a car geek, a food lover, and a goofy mom. I'm lucky enough--or foolish enough--to be able to turn most of my avocations into something resembling a vocation. Except for motherhood, but that's its own reward, right?

I was a record store geek back when there were record stores, and worked at the venerable (and late, lamented) Schoolkids' Records in Ann Arbor through college, while spinning jazz records at WEMU to the taxi drivers, barflies and night owls who listened during the wee hours. I then spent a dozen years as the corporate jazz buyer for the Borders Books & Music chain, a job that even in hindsight seems too good to be true.  After the music business--and Borders-imploded, I pursued another passion and joined the staff of AnnArbor.com as a food writer and community content coordinator. I spend a lot of time cooking, eating and writing, which also often feels too good to be true.
 
And now cars. I’ve been a car geek since I could walk. I caught the bug from my dad, who saved up the paychecks he earned pumping gas as a teen in western New York until he could afford a gorgeous vintage 1939 Oldsmobile. My first car was my parents’ old Dodge Spirit--an innocuous-looking car that hid a turbocharged V6 under the hood. That car took me all over the country--and fast. If I shoved a Kleenex in the tape player to stop the rattling, I could easily cruise at 120 mph, a thought that now--as a mom--strikes fear in my heart.

pageElements.text: I remember the afternoon we got sent home from the hospital with our new baby. No one checked to make sure that we weren’t too clumsy to hold him without dropping him.  There was no task force sent out to make sure we had bought a proper crib. We didn’t have to pass a swaddling test.
“Don’t you even want to follow us out to make sure we’ve got the car seat in right?” I asked the nurse.

“No, I’m sure you’ve got it just fine,” she assured us with a smile that let us know that we weren’t the first new parents to worry that we weren’t quite ready to be trusted with such an important bundle.
A few months into parenthood and the kid was still thriving, so I began to think that maybe we did have the skills to keep him alive. But I never stopped worrying about car seats.

There are all kinds of statistics to show us what kind of potential we parents have to screw it all up.  Vehicle crashes are the number one killers of children ages three to fourteen. Three out of four car seats are installed or used incorrectly.  It’s a wonder any kids make it to puberty.

For us, the biggest questions centered on when it was time to move to the next type of car seat. Each transition was anxiety inducing. Yeah, his legs are way too long to remain in the rear-facing seat, but are his neck muscles strong enough to hold that giant head up if we get in a collision? Yes, his five-point harness barely fits, but is he really ready for a booster seat?

When we finally decided that he was ready for a booster, I was ready to celebrate. Infant and convertible seats are expensive. Too expensive to buy for each car and each set of grandparents. So every time you switch cars, or send him off with Grandma for the day, you have to move the car seat over and reinstall it, all the while remembering that statistic about poorly installed car seats.

Boosters are awesome. Inexpensive. Easy to install. Someone else is taking your kid home from school? Just send him in with his own booster seat. There would be days when I’d see half a dozen boosters lining the hall at daycare, each labeled with the kid’s name in masking tape.

My son is ten now. We’re solidly in the post-car-seat years. I’ve handed them down or thrown them all away at this point. I’ve got six good years now. Six years when I don’t have to worry if I’m using the wrong car seat. Six years until I have to worry about him driving. God help me.

title: Interactive Cars: Coming Closer
subTitle: "Connected vehicles" are the subject of a major study based right here in JKC's town, Ann Arbor.
promoTeaserSmall: "Connected vehicles" are the subject of a major study based right here in JKC's town of Ann Arbor.
promoTeaser: "Connected vehicles" are the subject of a major study based right here in JKC's town of Ann Arbor.
metaTitle: Interactive Cars: Coming Closer - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Interactive Cars: Coming Closer. Learn about a major connected vehicle study from JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Since late August, Jean Knows Cars’ hometown of Ann Arbor, Michigan, has been playing host to the largest ever study of connected vehicles--technology that lets cars interact with one another out on the road. The study, administered by the U.S. Department of Transportation and the University of Michigan’s Transportation Research Institute (UMTRI), involves nearly 3,000 cars outfitted with special communication devices for research. The cars interact with one another and with signals posted permanently at intersections, on sharp curves, and on the M-14 and US-23 freeways. The study focuses on the northeast area of Ann Arbor, and participants will have the testing equipment installed in their cars over a twelve-month period. This connected vehicle study just got under way several weeks ago, part of a thirty-month overall research project. The UMTRI's director, Peter Sweatman, has said, “We feel honored to be hosting the national test environment for vehicles that don’t crash.”

Connected vehicles are getting more and more buzz lately, and for good reason. The UMTRI believes that the technology has the potential to reduce up to 80 percent of "unimpaired crashes," according to Francine Romine, director of communications at UMTRI. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration reports that there are more than 10 million car crashes yearly on American roads. In 2009, the most recent year for which there's data, there were 10.8 million accidents.

Of the cars participating in the study, the vast majority--about 2,800--carry a Vehicle Awareness Device, or VAD, which emits a signal that can be picked up by similar devices in other cars. Only about 300 cars carry a device that can both send and receive signals. Drivers of those cars get warnings when they are following another study-equipped vehicle too closely, when they may need to brake unexpectedly, or when they are approaching a sharp curve, among other things. Jim Sayer, UMTRI’s project manager for the study, says "the real benefits will come from [devices] that both transmit and receive," but in order to get that data, the cars need a large pool of signals to react to.

David Cahill, pictured here, is one of the Ann Arborites who volunteered for the connected vehicle study, and he told Jean Knows Cars about his experience. The vehicle awareness device in his car is one of the transmit-only variety.  He told us that, when the device was installed in early August, the other more advanced devices "were not yet ready or working." Although the study's piece of equipment equipment, a GPS antenna taped to his windshield and shown with this article, came unstuck the day after it was installed, UMTRI told him that signal transmission would not be interrupted, and they eventually repaired the device. Aside from that issue, Cahill says the device is "completely innocuous" and has not interfered with his driving at all.

Cahill became interested in the study after reading about it online. He says he is "really impressed with anything that will improve traffic safety and move toward automation," adding that he favors any technology that takes "second-to-second control of a two-ton vehicle" out of the hands of drivers.

At the end of the yearlong study, participants will receive $200. Cahill said this didn't have an impact on his choice to  participate. An interesting angle the study organizers took was to recruit among parents in the Ann Arbor Public Schools in the northeast side of town being studied, with the $200 being donated to school at the end. Romine of UMTRI said the study considered stay-at-home parents ideal candidates because of the amount of time they spend driving in the study area. Romine noted that parents often travel "12,000 to 13,000 miles a year just driving their kids."

A few commercial vehicles have also been outfitted, and UMTRI's Sayer says there is the potential for applications to be developed that could help long-haul truck drivers to find places to park overnight. Those applications don’t exist yet, but researchers at UMTRI and other institutions are looking into developing them.

Many in the industry and elsewhere consider connected vehicles as a crucial steppingstone to autonomous cars, although there is no reliable estimate for when cars could kick humans out of the driver’s seat. Sayer, for his part, expects that "there will be radar-based wireless and vehicle-based systems for a long time" before the leap to automation.

If the idea of hooking your car up to a wireless network concerns you, rest assured that a lot of effort has gone into making sure the network is secure. When signing up for the study, Cahill was assured that all data gathered from him or his vehicle would be kept private.

Sayer says that privacy concerns are not the biggest issue, since many of the devices used in the study do not store data. Rather, the concern is that "someone could introduce some rogue signals" into the environment, which could cause the devices to behave erratically. Sayer says that both device manufacturers and the federal government have worked to make the system secure.

It will take time to hear about the results of the study.  After collecting data from vehicles at several points throughout the year, UMTRI will send the data to the Department of Transportation for analysis. No matter what the results tell us about the future of driving and traffic safety, the study’s placement in Ann Arbor is meaningful to Michigan residents, who have faced years of hard times and doubts about the future of the auto industry in this state. Cahill says he is "delighted" that this largest-of-its-kind study has a home here.
And so are we! We will check back in on this study as the year progresses and bring you updates on how it's going.

title: Appearance: Black Is the New Black
subTitle: From a little trim to a complete monochromatic treatment, black is everywhere on cars now.
promoTitle: Appearance: Black Is the New Black
promoTeaserSmall: From a little trim to a complete monochromatic treatment, black is everywhere on cars now.
promoTeaser: From a little trim to a complete monochromatic treatment, black is everywhere on cars now.
metaTitle: Black Is the New Black -- JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Black is the new black when it comes to automotive exteriors and trim these days. Read about it as a style statement on cars in JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: There are drivers who want a car that can take them to work and back every day without breaking down, and then there are drivers who want a car that does that and is also exciting, distinctive, and fun to drive. As Ford design manager Melvin Betancourt puts it: “Everyone wants their ride to represent them.” Luckily for the second group, customization of cars is becoming easier, with automakers providing more and more options for choosy buyers. One of the latest trends–black accessories and paint jobs–might already seem like an old standby, but that doesn’t mean it’s boring.

Ford offers black wheels on seven models, including family vehicles like the Edge Sport and Flex. On the Flex, the black wheels are part of the $1,495 Titanium appearance package, perhaps best enjoyed when paired with that car’s optional black roof. Subaru offers dark wheels for its Impreza, and Crosstrek models, and the Dodge Dart Rallye also comes with black wheels, only $395 in that model. Of course, if you don’t want to buy a new car just for a slight style upgrade, you can always buy your rims online. Prices range from a couple of hundred dollars to a couple of thousand dollars for a set.
Ford says that the Flex’s black wheels have been growing in popularity. One example is car-crazy Los Angeles, where there is a 50 percent "take rate" for them.

Wheels aren’t the only part of the car that looks better in black. Jeep and BMW have both done black-themed special editions of vehicles. Jeep’s limited edition 2012 Patriot Altitude sports black paint, black wheels, and a black interior. BMW built twenty 2011 Frozen Black Edition M3 coupes that also wore black paint, black wheels, and a black interior–although they also featured eye-catching blue-and-red contrast stitching. Those ultra-limited-run cars were so coveted that they sold out in twenty-two minutes, according to BMW.

Land Rover’s new special edition Evoque, with Victoria Beckham as design consultant, features glossy black wheels and exterior accents as well as a dark interior touched with the edition’s signature rose gold. That Evoque is also a very limited run, with only 200 to be manufactured worldwide.

The black theme is perhaps most common among sports cars. In 2012, Porsche sold black editions of the Boxster S and 911. Mercedes-Benz has been widely reported to be testing an SLS AMG Black Edition. And then, of course, there’s the Batmobile, perhaps a mythical inspiration for all the sinister and shadowy limited editions. These real cars may not be able to fly, but they’ll certainly turn heads.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

contributors.bio:
Jean Jennings has been writing about cars and the car business for more than thirty years. She learned about cars at the kitchen table from her father Robert, the late editor of Automotive News. At the age of eighteen, she bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, Jennings went to Chrysler’s test track where she worked as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, she was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine when she was laid off her Chrysler job, and in 1985 she left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr., as its first executive editor. She became Editor-in-Chief in 2000 and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

Jennings has won awards for her feature writing, for her car reviews, and for her monthly Automobile Magazine column “Vile Gossip.” She was the recipient of the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism. Jennings has the unique experience, sensibility, and personality to connect with women and to give them voice in the male-dominated automotive space. She was the subject of a Susan Orlean profile in the New Yorker, has appeared on numerous television news shows, has been on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno, and was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000.

She is currently a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News.

Jennings lives in the Michigan countryside with her husband, Tim, and the entire food chain.

pageElements.text: One of the things I do as editor of Automobile Magazine is go to auto shows all over the world. Paris isn’t usually the most important auto show, although this year it was crazy with dozens of world premieres. But even on the sleepier year, the Paris show is one of my favorites for one big reason: it’s in Paris. And it’s in Paris at the right time of the year, late September. It happens every other year (just to build my enthusiasm), alternating with the much less glamorous (but way more important) Frankfurt show.

I like to arrive in Paris a couple of days early to visit my favorite boutiques and perfume store. The show itself I can see in one good day. It’s dominated by the three big French manufacturers—Renault, Citroen, and Peugeot—which never fail to deliver gorgeous displays and wacky concept cars. There’s so much going on, I thought it would be fun to just capture the insanity of it all with my Flip camera, also known as the JeanCam. Not the most professional video you’ve ever seen, but I hope you’ll enjoy just a glimpse of all the different things I did when I was there. I’m working on my technique for next time.

subTitle: Home furnishings with all the understated style you'd expect from Mercedes design.

metaDescription: Mercedes-Benz Style Comes Indoors. Mercedes-Benz's new furniture collection, showcased on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Mercedes-Benz's first furniture collection is rolling out this month, as the German automaker continues to expand its brand beyond luxury cars. Mercedes-Benz's Style division, in collaboration with the Italian Formitalia Luxury Group, will be choosing U.S. outlets for the furnishings this fall, and they'll be available for purchase for as yet undisclosed prices. Formitalia Design Group also offers Aston Martin and Lamborghini interior furnishings.

You won’t find the iconic three-pointed-star hood ornament adorning these high-end pieces, which include a sofa, a chaise longue, a dining room table, chairs, a sideboard, an  integrated home theater system with seating area, a chest of drawers, and a bed. Mercedes-Benz Style and   opted for a streamlined, minimalist approach to furniture design. You'll have to look carefully to find the subtle Mercedes-Benz Style logo on the pieces.

The unmistakable link to the cars is there in many ways, from wooden chair backs inspired by the seat shells in current Mercedes-Benz research vehicles to the sofa’s aluminum frame, which reminds one of the company's car design aesthetic. The dining table uses a central aluminum beam as well, with legs designed to look like sculptured wheel spokes. The sideboard has a glass door with a surrounding bezel that looks like the air intake on a sports car.
The Home Theatre System is painted in original Indium Silver metallic paint and has three wing-shaped wooden shelves--an evocative concept for any Mercedes-Benz connoisseur, to be sure.

Some of the top Mercedes-Benz designers are at work at Villa Salazar, the Advanced Design Studio, in Como, Italy. There, the late fashion designer Gianni Versace once made neckties. Mercedes-Benz said the designers are charged with tracking interior trends for homes as well as cars.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: The new Cadillac ATS and the farm markets near my home in the countryside go well together. I fit lots of chrysanthemums and pumpkins into the back of this car's trunk, so don't believe reports you may have read that it doesn't have a lot of trunk space. This is the 2013 Cadillac ATS 2.5L Luxury Collection model.

The Cadillac ATS is the new “baby” Cadillac designed to fight the Germans, and one weapon in that battle is  its aggressive pricing. It’s the smallest, lightest, least expensive Cadillac, but definitely not a repeat of the ill-fated Cadillac Cimarron from the 1980s.

This is a start-from-scratch model not derived from Opel or Chevrolet, and it was developed on a new lightweight rear-wheel-drive architecture. The 2013 ATS has one of the lowest curb weights in the segment; in  2.5-liter four-cylinder trim, it has a curb weight of 3,315 pounds. The lightweight approach is significant because it helps save at the pump.

The 2013 Cadillac ATS 3.6L Premium is the top of the range. It is $6,000 more expensive than the base 2013 Cadillac ATS. You can easily hit $50,000 if you add options such as Cadillac Cue, the new infotainment system that is bundled with a surround sound system and is priced at $1,350.

Standard safety features include eight air bags, stability control, and anti-lock brakes. Optional safety features include lane departure warning, side blind zone alert, forward collision alert, and intelligent brake assist. The cabin is customizable, with five distinct color choices available.
The chief competitors are the BMW 328i, Mercedes-Benz C250, and Lincoln MKZ.

title: Peace of Mind Tech for Parents of Teens
promoTitle: Peace of Mind Tech for Parents of Teens
promoTeaserSmall: Mercedes-Benz and Ford telematics can help you keep control over your car while your teen has it.
promoTeaser: Mercedes-Benz and Ford telematics can help you keep control over your car while your teen has it.
metaTitle: Peace of Mind Tech - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Maintain a strong peace of mind by learning about tech to track your car while your teen--or a valet--has it; from JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: It’s no secret that sending a new driver out on the road alone in a multi-thousand-pound missile is nerve-racking for the parents of teenagers, to say the least. Luckily, automakers are coming up with ways to ease the minds of nervous parents.

Ford’s MyKey technology, originally used in fleet vehicles to allow fleet owners a measure of control over their drivers, is now available with all vehicles that have Sync. MyKey allows a car owner to put limits on one of a vehicle’s keys, presumably the ones that belong to the teen driver. The limits can include a Persistent Ford Belt Minder, which will remind drivers to buckle up by sounding a chime at regular intervals and muting audio, an electronically limited top speed of 80 mph, and an early low fuel warning (at seventy-five miles instead of fifty miles until empty) to help absent-minded teens avoid being stranded.

Mercedes-Benz takes the limitations even further by allowing owners who drive cars equipped with mbrace2 to track their car’s movements, using what the automaker calls a "breadcrumb" method, via a dedicated mbrace website. Once logged in, owners can use the mbrace website to set their preferences to record what Mercedes-Benz calls a Driving Journal, which essentially directs the car to record its trip history, then makes that history viewable online. Through the mbrace website, owners can also set up zones on a map that they don’t want the car to enter – say, a bad neighborhood or your daughter’s boyfriend’s house. You can choose to be alerted when a car enters or exits the zones you have chosen. Owners can also choose to receive alerts when the car exceeds a certain speed or is started after curfew.

If you value serenity, it might be worth limiting the number of alerts you choose to receive from your Mercedes. It wouldn't be surprising if a teen driving a car with that many limitations were to break a rule about once every five minutes.

Perhaps the most revelatory thing about these technologies is the way that new drivers react to them. According to Ford, a poll of young drivers said that 67 percent of them initially disliked MyKey’s features – no shock there – but when paired with the idea that they would be allowed more access to a car, 64 percent were “more accepting” of the technology.

MyKey is standard equipment on almost all Ford and Lincoln vehicles. Mercedes-Benz's mbrace2 is a subscription service, available on all 2013 Mercedes-Benz models except the S- and CL-Class. The service costs $280 per year after a six-month free trial, with up to $28 in extra costs per month depending on the features you choose.
