contributors.bio: I've always had cars on the brain. I turned my first wrench when I was about four, growing up among my dad's collection of weird old British and American classics. In adolescence, I was rifling through back issues of Hot Rod and Car Craft, clipping out photos and articles on fire-breathing hot rods. And after adopting my mom's old Ford Escort, I started getting part-time jobs in garages, which sustained me all the way through college and grad school. I completed the restoration of my first car on student loans, and I currently own a total of four vintage vehicles, all of which I work on. Even after earning two academic degrees and toiling most of the way through a third, my heart remained in the garage, and just as my doctoral funding ran out, I got a break on a dream job that would allow me to combine my two major life passions: writing and cars. I've been writing about cars, covering motorsports and car shows, and having a ton of hell-raising adventures as an editor at CarDomain.com since 2007.

pageElements.text: A ton of ink has been spilled recently about the relative benefits of manual and automatic transmissions. What can all the fuss possibly be about, with both options having been around for decades? Well for one thing, today's computer-mediated automatic is hardly your grandma's slushbox: the increasing technological sophistication of modern automatics is one factor that is reinvigorating and galvanizing the debate. But even as robotically precise dual-clutch automatics and trippy continuously variable transmissions (CVTs) appear to be taking over the market, the sturdy manual trans is making a modest comeback, as I reported earlier this year. News reports last spring showed a near doubling in the “take rate” for manual transmissions, bringing the percentage of stick-equipped cars sold to the highest it’s been in five years. This may seem odd, especially since the eventual phasing-out of the manual has long been seen as a foregone conclusion.

So why the resurgence in interest? As it turns out, the good old stick shift has a number of enduring benefits that are, as they say, recession proof. And although there isn't a lot to say about the issue at this stage that's really news, all of us who have owned or loved a car equipped with a manual gearbox have at least a handful of ironclad reasons why they are the superior choice. Here are mine:

1. Mechanical simplicity. If you've done your homework, you're well versed in all the technobabble associated with the modern automatic transmission. But this is one area where it's possible to have too much of a good thing. A lot of the more cutting-edge innovations are still in their relative infancy, and driving vehicles that are so equipped, you can definitely feel it: you might think of the CVT, for example, as the new early-1990s airbag. Plus, there's no telling whether the new gadgetry will stand the test of time; as with touch screens and "smart" crash-avoidance systems, it’s impossible to know what kind of shape all that electronica will be in ten years down the road. While tech-loaded trannies can do some impressive things, they certainly require increasing levels of esoteric knowledge to work on, and there's something a little disconcerting about being so locked out of your own car. On some new automatics, you can't even check the fluid level anymore. By contrast, a manual gearbox is pretty much the same creature that it was forty years ago. Sure, they can come with glitchy tech, too, like hill-hold or skip-shift nannies, but for the most part these features are not integral to the unit's functioning. And unless you've ended up with the rare truly defective manual transmission, there's a whole lot less that can go wrong over the lifetime of your vehicle.

2. Extra cash. While it used to be that opting for the manual would guarantee you better gas mileage, today's computer-controlled automatics are optimized for fuel economy and shift more precisely to that end than any human being ever could. When you look at fuel mileage ratings between automatics and manuals for the same model, you'll find that, industry-wide, it's pretty much a wash: sometimes the manual still yields an edge of one or two mpg, sometimes the auto has the upper hand. So although saving money at the pump is no longer a big part of the conversation, a manual-equipped vehicle still has the ability to put extra money in your bank account at least twice during its lifetime: when you buy it, and when you get it serviced. A car with a stick shift still rings in at several hundred dollars cheaper than its automatic-equipped counterpart. The gap can become even more pronounced when you're shopping used cars, as dealers will often discount limited-market manuals deeply to move them out the door. As for service, see point number one above. A manual transmission is almost always more durable, uses fewer parts, and demands less frequent and less complicated service, and if anything ever goes seriously south, guess which unit you'd rather pay to replace.

3. Theft deterrence. Admittedly, the evidence for this claim is more anecdotal than anything, but a number of high-profile thwarted carjackings suggest that as manual proficiency declines among the general population, it becomes less and less likely that a criminal will know how to operate a vehicle so equipped. I'm more comfortable leaving my five-speed car idling unattended in my driveway than any automatic-equipped car, because I'm confident that any malcontent passing by won't even be able to figure out how to get it out of the driveway (for one thing, I swapped in a five-speed gearbox in place of the car's original four, so the pattern depicted on the shift knob is deceitfully inaccurate, but that's another story). Car thieves look for easy targets and paths of least resistance, and a manual trans is neither.

4. Less texting. Let's face it, it's a lot harder to twiddle on your mobile device when your right hand is otherwise occupied. Or balance a venti latte. Or juggle a batch of drive-through takeout, or do any of the other dumb-driver things that put your accident risk through the roof. While the mechanical aspect of this issue is a no-brainer, the benefits of driving a manual go beyond eliminating physical distractions. It's become a cliche for enthusiasts to claim that in a manual-equipped car you’re "more connected to the road," but it happens to be true: it's a different plane of driving, one that engages both your body and your mind. You become more focused; you burn more calories. Your parallel parking becomes an art form. Revolutions per minute and torque suddenly become a lot more meaningful. You're negotiating the subtle balance of throttle and clutch, as associate editor Annie White noted, and it forces you to pay more attention to traffic variables and road conditions, not to mention the propensities and limits of your particular vehicle. And since there are some things that are way harder to do when you're driving stick, like texting, you stop doing them and concentrate on the road instead.

5. Driving pleasure. As gas prices go up and family budgets go down, smaller and smaller fuel sippers are increasingly becoming the order of the day. No matter what other features you might consider important in a car, everyone wants the most fuel-efficient vehicle possible. The only problem is that, equipped with an automatic, most of these fuel-sipping compacts have about as much get up and go as a sack of rotten apples. But throw in a manual trans, and the balance of power shifts (!). Even the most apathetic and wheezy econobox will get an infusion of guts once you're able to drive it the way you want to, breathing new life into even the most lethargic commute. I mean, come on: if you can chirp the tires off the line in your Hyundai Accent, or throw a nice downshift to beat it through a yellow light when you’re five minutes away from the start of your first meeting, you know it's going to be a good day.

Start Your Engines

If you don't know how to drive stick yet, don't sweat it. People always speak solemnly about how they're "going to learn how to drive standard" like they're working themselves up to apply to law school, but it's really not all that big a deal. While the best way to learn manual as executive editor Laura Brown discovered under duress, any immersion situation will do. Borrow a friend's manual-equipped car for a week and drive yourself to work in it every day. Or, if no one will lend you one, spend a few hundred bucks on a Craigslist junker and tool around in a parking lot until you get the hang of it (you can always sell it afterwards). And then don't be afraid to buy your forever car with the manual trans even if you haven't fully mastered it yet. When you look at the whole picture, driving manual is really just a way of beating the system while still playing by the rules. Sure, you can still be a goody two-shoes and drive a fuel-efficient car, but, by gum, you'll get some fun out of it. You'll spend less and enjoy more. And you'll get more in all those ways that don't have anything to do with money. Shift happy, and enjoy the ride!

title: Volvo Traffic Jam Assistance
promoTeaserSmall: Volvo will roll out its newest autonomous technology, a traffic jam assistance system, in 2014.
promoTeaser: Volvo will roll out its newest autonomous technology, a traffic jam assistance system, in 2014.
metaTitle: Volvo Traffic Jam Assistance - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Volvo Traffic Jam Assistance: Learn about Volvo's newest autonomous driver-aid system. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: What if you could take the hundreds of hours per year that the average American driver spends commuting, and wring the majority of the stress out of all that driving time? There just might be a way, because we’ve just learned about Volvo’s latest technological breakthrough, the Traffic Jam Assistance System.

If you have spent any amount of time commuting in heavy traffic, you know the frustration of crawling along for miles as your life ticks by, alternately slamming on the brakes and cooling your heels while traffic moves in fits and starts. Imagine, if you will, a feature that lets you relax while the car autonomously keeps you at a safe following distance in slow-moving traffic.

This is Volvo's Traffic Jam Assistance technology. It is an evolution of Volvo’s adaptive cruise control and lane keeping systems, which were rolled out on the Volvo V40 earlier this year. When the driver pushes a button, the engine, brakes, and steering respond automatically to maintain a set distance behind the vehicle ahead when traffic is moving at those frustratingly low speeds up to 31 mph.

Volvo notes that this technology is not just a way to make commuting less annoying. It also can help cut fuel consumption and improve traffic flow—which could reduce the amount of time you have to spend in a slow-moving line, so it’s all good.

Already, the Swedish automaker is looking to get government support in the United States for standardized regulation of the autonomous driving experience. Volvo R&D chief Peter Mertens spoke in Washington, D.C., earlier this week about “policy implications of autonomous vehicles” in a talk co-sponsored by the Embassy of Sweden, during which he called for research by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) and eventual performance ratings on autonomous driving technology. Volvo is concerned, he said, that state-by-state regulation could restrict and discourage the smooth implementation of autonomous driving technology.

It all feels very Jetsons-like, but this is no mere concept. Volvo anticipates a 2014 rollout for the technology, although it didn’t reveal which vehicles will get it. That’s not a moment too soon for those of us who loathe crawling along in bumper-to-bumper traffic. Mertens says it’s among the first steps toward “our vision that future cars will not crash at all.”
How do you say “Amen” in Swedish?

promoLarge.title: You Auto Know: Changing a Flat Tire

header.title: You Auto Know: Changing a Flat Tire

pageElements.text: Changing a flat tire is not a pleasant task, but sometimes you just have to do it. Besides, it's good for the soul to know how.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/3dgM1I-iTSE?list=PLDtKaZSQcnJDBKK4xQsBeRQm1nY0FMAyv" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

In addition to showing you how, this video illustrates the value of being prepared ahead of time. Look at your owner's manual and check out your vehicle at a time when you're safely parked at home and have no flat tire to worry about. Make sure you know where the jack is located in your car and how to assemble and use it, and find out where the spare tire is housed and learn how to remove it.

Lots of vehicles carry small, lightweight temporary spare tires now instead of full-size spare tires. That's an easy way for the automaker to cut weight and improve fuel economy on your car, but know that the word "temporary" is no joke. These tires are only intended to get you to your dealer or a repair shop, not to be driven on for any length of time.

One last safety note: If you do get a flat tire out on the road, make sure there is a truly safe place to pull over. If you have to drive some distance to safety on a flat tire, it will ruin that tire and probably damage the wheel, but that's preferable to endangering yourself and your passengers.

contributors.bio:
I don’t understand people who dislike driving. I really don't. The freedom of getting behind the wheel of a car and just taking off can't be compared with anything else. You really feel that you’re in charge: in charge of the car, in charge of the road, and in charge of your life. Why on earth would you want someone else to drive you around when you could do it yourself? It’s so liberating! Obviously, I love driving. I suppose that isn't a particularly original statement for a Detroit native, but it's true. I was a little late getting my driver's license because of that pesky parallel parking, but once I got it, nothing could stop me. It doesn't matter if I have to chauffeur my grandmother to the bank less than a block from our house or drive across town. If I have my green Chrysler LHS--affectionately christened "Betsy" by my mother--and some gas in the tank, and if I am somehow able to avoid getting pulled over for driving just a little too fast, I'm good to go.

Since I graduated from the University of Michigan, in April 2012, Betsy has taken me everywhere. She has been my steadfast companion on trips to buy more supplies for various sewing projects, leisurely drives along Jefferson/Lakeshore Drive in Grosse Pointe Shores, Michigan, and frequent jaunts to the bookstore to buy yet another copy of Hamlet, a 500-plus-page book on Elizabeth I, or a good book on British history that isn’t as dry as a piece of chalk…And, yes, there is a little bit of theme there. Not only am I a bibliophile, but I’m also a self-proclaimed Anglophile who loves Shakespeare and Elizabethan verse and one day plans to see the Houses of Parliament, visit the Tower of London, and, perhaps most important, eat real fish and chips. If only I could drive Betsy "across the pond…"

pageElements.text: You can still see the USA in your Chevrolet, but not from the front bench of your sedan for much longer. And if you are old enough to remember that TV commercial, the end of this era might actually make you feel sad. The 2013 Chevrolet Impala pictured here is the last of a dying breed. After this model year, the front bench seat will no longer be an option on the traditional big sedan.

While SUVs and trucks will continue to have bench seats available, the Impala will be the last passenger car that General Motors makes with them in the front. It was preceded by the Buick Century, which was last offered with 55/45 split bench seats for the 2005 model year, and the Buick LaCrosse, which last saw bench seats in 2009; those were an atypical 40/20/40 split arrangement. The three-across seating had been on Chevrolets from the start, appearing on the very first Chevy, which was the 1911 Series C Classic Six.

Before and after photos: Bench seats in GM cars were ubiquitous from the Twenties through the Sixties. I made a pilgrimage over to the local Chevrolet dealer to have a look at the last bench seat in a 2013 Chevrolet Impala LT sedan in the new-car lot. The seat is a $195 option in a car with a $27,385 MSRP, so surely it's more taste than price that is keeping buyers away. That, and the fact that this is not exactly a traditional bench seat anymore.

GM isn't explaining why it has finally killed the bench seat, but it's likely a simple case of lack of demand. GM data show that only one in ten Impala buyers chose to pay the additional $195 for the front bench seat last year, when it was an option on the LS and LT. Clay Dean, GM director of design, said that customers have gone to bucket seats "because they're sporty, even in models that aren't sports cars. Our customers also appreciate having the center console as a convenient place to store their phone and other personal items."

From a consumer’s purely speculative viewpoint, the switch could also be due to the bench seat’s lack of lateral support. I drive my dad’s 1988 Buick Park Avenue when my Chrysler is out of commission. Unlike the seats in the Chrysler, the Buick, which I have christened Oliver, has leather split-bench seats that are soft and well broken in from supporting people much taller and heavier than I am. They generally aren’t a problem, but when I turn a corner while driving old Oliver, I slip and slide from left to right just a little more than I’d like. But you know, I will probably miss the bench seat option once it's no longer available.

And GM design chief Dean may have thought of that. "You never know," he said, "we might see bench seats re-emerge someday, possibly in very small cars like the EN-V urban mobility concept vehicle, in which the feeling of open space may be very desirable."

title: Going for 300K
promoTeaserSmall: In our disposable culture, you still can find high-mile cars and people who won't stop driving them.
promoTeaser: In our disposable culture, you still can find high-mile cars and people who won't stop driving them.
metaTitle: Going for 300K: High-Mileage Cars and the People Who Love Them - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Going for 300K: Read about people who love their high-mileage cars and don't want to give them up at JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Despite the fact that I grew up just outside of Detroit, I was never particularly infatuated with cars. It wasn't until I headed to Washington, D.C., and began working for an environmental trade journal that I got an up close and personal look at what it takes to design an automobile. My first articles focused on efforts by legislators to make once heavily polluting cars run cleaner. When I moved back to Michigan, that became my focus as I contributed extensively to the Detroit bureaus of both the New York Times and Newsweek. I became fascinated by how the automobile impacts so many aspects of our lives and reflects our styles and preferences. Over the past two dozen years as a freelancer, I've covered the auto industry for a wide variety of publications, including Popular Mechanics, Scientific American, iVillage, Automotive News, Ad Age, Hemispheres, Technology Review, and AARP. I've also contributed pieces on air to public radio. My coverage has focused on such issues as the ways domestic automakers will respond to increasingly tough mandates for fuel-efficient cars while still designing vehicles that appeal to consumers, and my firsthand—and slightly scary—experience driving an autonomous car. But my stories are less about the vehicle than the person driving it. I'm most intrigued by the way people shape cars and cars shape those who drive them.

pageElements.text: I'm driving down a country road in Ohio on the way to visit my son in college. With every hesitation in acceleration, spark and sputter, or burning smell, I'm praying that the car won't die. I'm envisioning what it would be like to break down here, surrounded by nothing but miles of cornfields.

I swapped my minivan with my husband this morning and am driving his 1998 Honda Accord. The car has 290,000 miles on it, and my husband is excessively excited at the prospect of watching the odometer hit 300,000. Each time we take the car in for a major repair, as we did last summer when we paid $400 for a new radiator, and I question the value of keeping this car going, he is quick to reply, "It's only the same as one car payment."

The car can't fit in the original garage of our ninety-two-year-old house, since it was designed for a Model T, so Old Faithful is finally showing its age, with patches of rust and peeling paint. My husband now parks it inconspicuously at the back of his parking lot at work. But our children would happily drive his car rather than my minivan. It's understandable, since it's exactly the type of car a teenager would receive as a hand-me-down. As much as I have griped about my husband's stubborn refusal to take his vehicle on one final drive to the junkyard, I was astonished, after polling my friends, to find out how many others are hanging on to their high-mileage cars.

And we're not alone. According to a Polk study done two years ago, consumers keep a new vehicle for about 63.9 months, up 4.5 months from data Polk collected in 2009. The average age of vehicles on the road has hit a record level of 10.8 years for cars and light trucks; that number was only 9.7 in 2006. Financial concerns fueled by the recession, but also vehicles' improved longevity, help explain the trend, said Paul Taylor, chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association (NADA). "And some people just become attached to their vehicles and they just keep on driving them," he said.

The race to 300,000. That's certainly the case for Michael Simon of Ann Arbor, Michigan, whom my husband is racing to hit the 300,000 mark. A breast cancer oncologist at the Barbara Ann Karmanos Cancer Institute in Detroit, he could easily afford a new car. But instead, he's still driving his 2001 Honda Accord, purchased in November 2000, which has racked up 282,000 miles. Simon drives ninety-two miles to work round trip, and he says he expects to keep his car as long as it's safe. He feels that "if it's not broken, don't get rid of it." And, he adds: "I know the car. I have a sense of pride of taking care of it."

images.fileName: Deborah Queen High Mileage Car 622 x 350.jpg

pageElements.text: No car payments. Deborah Queen (pictured above), who lives in Royal Oak, Michigan, bought two used cars in May. The first was a 2001 Pontiac Grand Am with 155,398 miles on it that she said had a "spotless" maintenance record. After paying $3,800 for the car, she invested $1,000 to have it painted and fix the nicks and dings, since she didn't want to "drive a rust bucket." She and her husband also bought a 2005 Suzuki Aerio with 97,000 miles on it for $4,800. Her husband will "drive it till it dies," she said. She appreciated being able to "basically get two cars for the price of one." Queen says she'd rather spend her money on music lessons for her two daughters, which cost $400 a month, than have a car payment.

Julaine LeDuc, a resident of Ann Arbor, had so much confidence in her 2003 Mazda MPV, which has more than 200,000 miles, that she just passed it down to her twenty-three-year-old son. Ellen Keefe-Garner, who lives in the same neighborhood, did the same, handing her 2000 Honda CR-V with 220,000 miles on it to her twenty-one-year-old daughter. She learned that her old cars hold their value after selling a 2000 Honda Civic with 250,000 miles for $4,000 after two prospective buyers got into a bidding war. Her mechanic, Wally Hayes of Select Auto Service, told her that her current car, a 2006 Honda Civic with 100,000 miles, is one of the lowest-mileage cars he repairs; 40 to 50 percent of the cars he services have more than 150,000 miles, he said.

High-mileage cars can be reliable, safe vehicles, says Robert Ayers, an owner of Ayers Automotive Repair in Santa Barbara, California. He said he's worked on a car that had 350,000 miles, and that cars of many makes and models can enjoy long life, provided the owner takes good care of it and brings it in for regular maintenance. He says roughly fifteen percent of the vehicles he services have more than 150,000 miles on them. "People don't see the value in spending the kind of money a new car costs," he said. He speaks from experience; Ayers owns a BMW 525 with 265,000 miles that he plans to drive until it reaches 500,000.

Lauren Fix, a spokesperson for the Car Care Council, says it's also important to read the owner's manual to make sure you're following appropriate service procedures and that you're regularly changing the oil, checking fluids, and keeping an eye on rubber parts that are prone to wear. "The reason vehicles last a long time is that people take care of them the moment something comes up," she said.
I'll likely be subject to our sputtering "little engine that could" for at least nine more months. That's when my husband has promised to finally say goodbye to his long-lasting method of transport.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

metaDescription: Here's my take on the high-quality 2013 Acura ILX Tech on Jean's Driveway, only on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
Acura's ILX is the Honda division's new entry-level model, the smallest sedan in Acura's lineup since the Integra. It's aimed at "youth with maturity," Honda says.
The Tech we tested is one step up from the bottom of the ILX lineup at $32,295, including the $895 destination charge. The top-of-the-line ILX Hybrid, Acura's first Hybrid, starts at $29,795; with the Technology package, it starts at $35,295, including $895 destination.  
Spun off the Honda Civic, the ILX uses the Civic platform and wheelbase, but has a wider track and body—and more traditional instrumentation, without the Civic plastics in the cabin.

Standard on this model:
    • leather-trimmed sport seats
    • power moonroof
    • push-button ignition
    • Tech package, which bundles a navigation system and a communications system with real-time traffic and weather, dual-zone climate control and Acura/ELS surround sound system with ten speakers
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/lEVsmIEtSyo?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Standard safety equipment includes:
    • six air bags
    • anti-lock brakes
    • stability control
    • hill start assist
    • tire-pressure monitoring system

Chief competitors:
    • Audi A3 (base price $28,165)
    • Buick Verano (base price $23,965)
    • Hyundai Sonata (base price $21,670)
    All prices include destination charges

title: Speed-Limit Ride-Along: I Can't Drive 55
subTitle: The truth behind getting pulled over.
promoTeaserSmall: Think you got pulled over for driving a red car? Our associate editor says "Think again."
promoTeaser: Think you got pulled over for driving a red car? Our associate editor says "Think again."
metaTitle: Speed-Limit Ride-Along: I Can't Drive 55 - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Speed-Limit Ride-Along: I Can't Drive 55. Learn the real reasons for your latest traffic ticket when Annie White goes for a ridealong with local police. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Speed limits and drivers have been at odds for as long as they have existed in the same universe. I was born much too late for Sammy Hagar’s ode to reckless driving to inform my teenage years, but I still occasionally find myself chanting “I can’t drive 55” when zooming down rural roads well above the posted speed limit. I was doing just that this summer when I was pulled over and ticketed for doing 65 in a 55-mph zone in southern Michigan. I normally don’t mind getting pulled over, because normally I know I deserve it. But something about that incident got under my skin, so I decided to get to the bottom of this whole “speed limit” thing.

In an effort to make sense of the laws I have always considered oppressive, I spent a few hours riding around in a police car with Officer Jason Kitts of the Ann Arbor Police Department, tracking down the hardened criminals who disregard traffic laws in our fair city. And now, for your convenience, I have compiled a list of the things I learned during my trip behind the veil.

You’re (Probably) Not Being Profiled
The conventional wisdom about ticket enforcement says that if you’re a young man driving a bright red sports car, or a black man blasting rap music, you’re going to get pulled over pretty much no matter what. Officer Kitts promised that the car you drive doesn’t matter to him when he pulls you over (half of the cars we pulled over that afternoon were Mazdas, but that may say more about Mazda owners than police officers): "[Car] color doesn’t matter, car type doesn’t matter, male, female, hot, not hot. Doesn’t matter. Whoever’s going faster.”

Kitts conceded that it was possible that other officers cared about such minutiae, but at least in Ann Arbor, racial profiling is not left up to chance. After every stop, Officer Kitts had to fill out a form that recorded not only the type of incident and type of citation, but the age, gender, and race of the driver as well as whether the officer knew the person’s race before pulling them over. According to Kitts, the city of Ann Arbor conducted a year-long study to determine whether members of a certain race were being targeted over others. “You know what we found? We pull over old, white people.” Which, in case you’ve never been to Ann Arbor, sounds just about right.

Quotas
Quotas are like the giant squids of the law enforcement world: we’re pretty sure they exist, but we’ve never seen one in the flesh. Michigan has a law in effect prohibiting the establishment of monthly ticket quotas, and Officer Kitts was very clear that he was not subject to meeting a quota.

When I met up with him after lunch, he had already written nine tickets that day, a number that he regarded as fairly typical. He did allow that there was an “expectation” that officers assigned to a specialty unit write 100 tickets a month and that there is a monthly review of each officer’s statistics, but said that officers who didn’t meet that mark wouldn’t face any adverse consequences. He said he felt “some” pressure to keep his numbers of tickets up, especially in relation to temporary officers on his beat. “If you come in to be a temporary officer you shouldn’t beat me,” he said. But no firm quotas. They promise.

There Really Is a Permanent Record
My high school principal was great fan of invoking the so-called “permanent record.” If he was to be believed, every detention served or class skipped would be recorded and sent to future colleges and employers, who would, of course, be horrified by my juvenile delinquency. That is not real. However, if you’ve ever been pulled over and ticketed by a police officer, even if it was a long time ago or in a different state, that will stay with you. Take it from me.

I have been pulled over for speeding eight times and received three tickets. Every one of those tickets is preserved in excruciating detail on an Internet database somewhere, a database that was accessed by Officer Kitts once he had my license number. The ticket I got in Indiana for going 87 mph on the freeway three years ago was right up top, followed by a ticket for improper lane use in East Lansing two years ago, followed by that obnoxious citation from Calhoun County this summer. Officer Kitts could also see that the probationary period on my license was extended when I was seventeen, and that I had received a letter from the Secretary of State encouraging me to take a defensive driving course. He could also see that I had taken and successfully completed said course (though he couldn’t tell that I spent every minute of it in complete mental agony). After joking about my questionable driving habits, Officer Kitts warned me: “If you get pulled over in twenty years, this will all still be here.”
Just what I was hoping for.

metaTitle: An Adventure in Oil Changing - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: An Adventure in Oil Changing: Learn how to change your oil all by yourself. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

I am Gabrielle Taylor George, and I graduated in 2011 from Pioneer High School in Ann Arbor, Michigan, the city I was born and raised in. The words that describe me are DRIVE, determination, enterprise, initiative, eagerness, motivation, resolve, enthusiasm, hunger, commitment, sense of purpose. I have this crazy dream to become a great photographer and to have studios all over. I believe that we're put on this planet to enjoy life, that we have everything we would ever need to dream big, and that we can achieve the dream. I grasp the concept of first working for it, then deserving it. I believe it's up to you to take the wheel of the car that represents you and drive down that dark road—only seeing so much of what's ahead, not knowing but continuing anyway because there is no fear. Carry on and expect the best. When the worst comes around, keep driving.  And so far, I’ve only landed in jobs that support my dreams. I don’t want to stop for anybody.

pageElements.text: About a month ago, the dreaded “change oil soon” message popped up on my dashboard. I ignored it for a few weeks, as is my custom, but avoidance can only go on for so long. After reading a piece from Jean Knows Cars contributor Jen Dunnaway about her own first oil change, I decided that instead of taking my car to the gas station down the street for its oil change, I would do it myself. Why not?

I made a trip to my friendly neighborhood auto parts store armed with all the information I thought I needed – the type and amount of oil my car takes (you can find this information in your owner’s manual), the knowledge that I would need an oil filter, and a vague idea that I would need wrenches and maybe a few other tools. For your convenience, I compiled a list of the tools I needed for my project:

1. Ramps (or jack and jack stands) to elevate car,
    2. Wrenches: Box-end wrench, oil filter wrench, ratchet
    3. Rubber mallet
    4. Drain pan
    5. Oil filter (the right one for your car; ask at auto parts store)

There’s a fair amount of discussion among women who like cars about the fact that car enthusiasm is something of a boys’ club. But even though I was the only woman in O’Reilly’s when I went, no one in the store seemed to give it a second thought. They didn’t come up to offer patronizing advice, even though I probably could have used it. No one offered to carry my armload of equipment, and they didn’t offer to carry anyone else’s, either. I did get the only “have a nice day” of the morning when I walked out the door. Maybe this makes me a bad feminist, but I’m okay with a little gender bias when it gets me pleasant interaction with strangers.

1. Elevate car
     After a thorough reading of oil change instructions I found on Google, I elevated the car on some ramps we had at the office and got started. You can also use a jack and jack stands to raise the car and give you access to the oil pan and filter.

2. Unscrew cap and drain plug
     Once my car had been elevated, I unscrewed the oil fill cap. Like punching an extra hole in a beer to shotgun it, the open cap will help the oil drain more smoothly. Then, I moved on to unscrewing the drain plug. Actually, to be perfectly honest, someone else did this for me because it was on too tight for my weak little arms. If you’ve always had your oil changed professionally, they may have tightened your drain plug so that it’s hard to untighten by hand, so be prepared to work at it a little.

It’s also a good idea to make sure you have a wrench that is the right size for your drain plug before you start. I didn’t do this because I don’t like to plan ahead, but luckily I had a fifteen-millimeter box-end wrench that was close enough for rock’n’roll, and the plug was persuaded loose with the application of significant force. If you’re having trouble, try hitting your wrench with a rubber mallet for some extra leverage, but be careful not to strip the plug’s threading.

3. Let oil drain out
    Waiting for the oil to drain was probably my favorite part of this whole process. The used oil had that fantastic garage-y smell that I’ve always loved. My grandpa has perhaps the best-smelling garage in the whole world. He’s worked on cars there since before I was born, and you can tell. I aspire to one day have a garage as great as his, but until then I have to make do with the occasional sweet nostalgia of the smell of gasoline and old motor oil.

4. Replace oil filter
    I didn’t quite manage to catch all the oil in my drain pan, so I cleaned up a little before replacing my oil filter. My owner’s manual didn’t tell me which type of filter I would need, but I was able to look it up in a guide at the parts store. There are several different types of oil filters, and they can be mounted in different parts of the car. Some can be tightened and loosened by hand. My car’s filter is top mounted and requires a special tool to loosen it, which is where I ran into my second problem.

I thought I had adequately prepared for the challenge of a top-mounted filter by buying a 32-mm socket, but I had failed to buy the ratchet that would allow me to turn the socket and loosen the oil filter cap. This is when I was really glad I had done this at the office instead of at home, because if I’d been home I would have had to walk to the nearest parts store and suffer the shame of asking for help, but since I was at the offices of a car magazine, I just borrowed the tools and expertise from one of my coworkers.
Out came the old filter and in went the new one. When replacing the filter, you should smear a little oil on the gasket first; this helps form a seal when you screw it back in.

5. Put the new oil in
    With the filter and drain plug screwed back in I poured five quarts of new oil into the engine. Then I screwed the cap back on, checked the oil level (twice, actually. I was nervous) and called it a day. The instructions I read suggested holding back a portion of the new oil until after you run the engine and check for leaks, but I didn’t do this because I forgot. As far as I can tell, the most important thing is that when you’re done, the oil level is at the desirable range. Check this by taking out your dipstick, wiping it off, reinserting it, pulling it back out, and making sure that the level is at or near (but not above) the maximum level indicated on the stick. Make sure to dispose of your used oil properly. You should be able to recycle it safely at an auto parts store, service center, or recycling center.

I’ve always been one of those people who think the car runs better on a full tank of gas, and I know it’s not true, but I still believe my trusty steed is happier right after a fill-up. I had a similar feeling when I started the car up after what turned out to be a successful oil change. I couldn’t help but feel proud that my car still worked and the engine hadn’t seized up. I plan to change my own oil from now on, just maybe not in the middle of the workday when I’m wearing a new blouse.

pageElements.text: The Specialty Equipment Market Association trade show, also known as SEMA, is packed with a lot of custom cars on display, from the breathtaking to the outright bizarre, but we're partial to the 2013 Ford Mustang GT SEMA Build Powered by Women. It was the project of the SEMA Businesswomen's Network, in partnership with the Ford Motor Company and with Source Interlink Media, the parent company of Jean Knows Cars.

Ford designer Jennifer Seely submitted the winning design for the project, and forty-four aftermarket companies provided more than $60,000 worth of goods to help a group of women build this car. It made its debut at the show on Tuesday, October 30, and will be auctioned for the SEMA Memorial Scholarship Fund.
The Mustang will be listed for auction for the next ten days; read all about it here.

The project came together in four sections: powertrain group, undercarriage and suspension, interior and stereo system, and paint. Theresa Contreras, who does a lot of custom vehicles with L&G Enterprises, submitted a design that wasn't chosen, but she headed up the paint effort that resulted in the stunning satin finish set off by rose gold chrome accents inside and out. The project Mustang has a glass roof, quilted suede seats, and a custom leather interior, not to mention an Edelbrock E-Force supercharger and a custom sound system.

There were thirty-six women who actually turned a wrench on the car. They were chosen from among seventy women who applied to participate from around the country. Those selected came to El Segundo, California, as volunteers to work together. A total of fifty were involved in the build; the other fourteen worked in product procurement, marketing, and communications for the project. You can read their bios here. The first wrench was turned on July 9, although the planning began months earlier. The car was completed on September 27.

Crew chief Kellie Colf said the value of the experience transcended the build itself. "Once we were strangers, now we're lifelong friends," Kellie said. She told JKC that there were no personality conflicts, "no wrench throwing, just a really professional group of women." When Jean Jennings asked members of the team what the best part of the experience was, they were unanimous: "The camaraderie." As they talked about this bonding experience among women who freely admitted they were tomboys and didn't have a lot of female friends as kids, both Jean and Kellie got a little choked up. Understandably.

title: In-Car Tech: Infotainment
promoTeaserSmall: A tech-wary driver steps out of her comfort zone to test some of the hottest infotainment systems.
promoTeaser: A tech-wary driver steps out of her comfort zone to test some of the hottest infotainment systems.
metaTitle: In-Car Tech: Infotainment - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: In-Car Tech: Infotainment: Learn about some of the latest in-car infotainment systems at JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

I am Gabrielle Taylor George, and I graduated in 2011 from Pioneer High School in Ann Arbor, Michigan, the city I was born and raised in. The words that describe me are DRIVE, determination, enterprise, initiative, eagerness, motivation, resolve, enthusiasm, hunger, commitment, sense of purpose. I have this crazy dream to become a great photographer and to have studios all over. I believe that we're put on this planet to enjoy life, that we have everything we would ever need to dream big, and that we can achieve the dream. I grasp the concept of first working for it, then deserving it. I believe it's up to you to take the wheel of the car that represents you and drive down that dark road—only seeing so much of what's ahead, not knowing but continuing anyway because there is no fear. Carry on and expect the best. When the worst comes around, keep driving.  And so far, I’ve only landed in jobs that support my dreams. I don’t want to stop for anybody.

pageElements.text: I’m not what you'd call an obsessive when it comes to in-car technology. And if you're not, either, it's good you've come here. When I’m driving my car, I use the radio presets and the AUX input cable and nothing else. If I need directions, I use my iPhone, or I guess (I’m a horrible travel companion because I love getting lost). If I’m in a new car and it takes me more than a few minutes to figure out the sound system, I just turn on my iPhone speakers and stick that sucker on the dash. Instant surround sound.

Recently, I was forced out of my comfort zone when I participated in a comparison test run by our sister publication, Automobile Magazine. It compared six different information and entertainment systems (three from luxury brands, three from mainstream brands) and two different user experiences: mine and that of Automobile Magazine associate web editor Ben Timmins. In the name of science, we tested each car in the same categories: voice and manual entry of a point of interest (we used a favorite nearby lunch spot, Zingerman’s Bakehouse), voice and manual control of the radio, voice and manual adjustments to climate control, Bluetooth pairing of a phone, voice and manual control of the phone, and voice and manual selection of a song from an iPod.

The Talking Car Is Real
The first system we tested was Cue, from Cadillac. With hindsight, I know that this system has by far the most intuitive voice commands. Unlike many other systems, Cue will understand if you use mild slang (“yep” or “nope” instead of “yes” or “no”) and thanks to the music database Gracenote, it also understands colloquial names for bands (“The Boss” instead of “Bruce Springsteen,” say).

Voice commands can feel intimidating. It often feels to me as if there is an endless secret menu of commands I could use, and it's hard to know which one to select. Some systems may have an extensive array of commands but will guide you to the correct command so you don’t have to hit the “voice” button and then drive around in silence for twenty seconds before deciding what to say. Usually, it’s best to start with the general category or device you want to use. If you’re looking for directions, commands like “destination,” “point of interest,” or “navigation” will usually set you on the right path. If you want to listen to music, try “radio,” “iPod,” or “USB.”

images.caption: Audi MMI Touch
Cadillac CUE
Cadillac CUE
MyFord Touch
BMW iDrive
Hyundai Bluelink

pageElements.text:
Will We Be Lost Forever?
Our point of interest was a little obscure for the Point of Interest (POI) databases – they usually look for restaurants with twenty or more locations, and Zingerman’s Bakehouse is one of a kind. However, this did give us the opportunity to test the versatility of Internet search functions. Of the six systems, Audi's MMI and BMW's iDrive were able to find the Bakehouse with an impressively low amount of fuss. MMI integrates an online search into the Point of Interest menu. Once we were online, it was smooth sailing. BMW’s iDrive doesn’t connect to the Internet, but it does appear to have the most extensive POI database. Toyota's Entune was also able to find the Bakehouse by piggybacking onto the Internet provided by my iPhone to search Bing. Internet connectivity runs about $30 a month for Audi owners, and Entune services cost up to $45 per month, but only after a generous and free three-year subscription. The other systems failed to find the Bakehouse, altough if you happen to be driving a Cadillac equipped with OnStar (we were), you can make a phone call and have directions downloaded to your car’s navigation system quite quickly.

I had my biggest battle on the navigation front with the beleaguered MyFord Touch system, which was able to find Zingerman’s Delicatessen (a sister restaurant), but stumbled on the final command. It then restarted the whole process and never found the Deli again even though I drove around our office park four or five times, having an increasingly testy exchange with the lady who lives in the dashboard.

Buttons to the Rescue
Luckily for those of us who hate listening to a car talk, you can always substitute voice commands for manual entry of any command you care to use. All but two of the systems we tested used touchscreens for control of the infotainment system, with Audi MMI and BMW iDrive using rotary dials (combined with a PDA-like touchscreen with MMI which allows you to spell out words using your fingers). I far prefer using the rotary dial to select letters and move through the system, which I found to be substantially easier and less distracting than the touchscreen. (Let me now take a moment to remind you that entering text into your infotainment system while driving is a horrible idea. I know most people do it, but you shouldn’t.) That said, most of the touchscreens were acceptably responsive and precise, so it’s really just a matter of preference.

For most of our other tests, the systems were all fairly competent. Audi MMI does not allow you to use voice commands to control an iPod or other music device, but it does allow you to select a song manually; if you fill up the in-car hard drive with music you can ask for a song by voice. I often had a hard time finding my way around the radio systems, but if you drove any of these cars every day you would become accustomed to its quirks quickly. Ford’s Sync system (separate from, but included with, MyFord Touch) and Cadillac’s Cue were particularly skilled at quick, seamless music selection.

All the systems had easy, reliable steps for Bluetooth phone pairing. Climate control by voice was only available in one system, MyFord Touch, and it was frustrating and, to my mind, would usually be unnecessary.

The Verdict
If I had to buy my next car based on the infotainment system alone, I would pick a BMW. It was the least frustrating and most intuitive to use, and it has a cool head-up display that displays your next navigation steps discreetly on the windshield so you can look like you know where you’re going even if you don’t. But the bottom line is that if your car is more than a few years old, any of these systems will be a huge upgrade. Just be prepared for a learning curve.
The Details

Audi MMI
Availability: The model we tested, which included Audi Connect, is available in the allroad, A6, A7, A8, and Q7.
Cost: Varies depending on model; $3,050 as a stand-alone option.
Favorite feature: The rotary dial.
Least favorite feature: No voice control of my iPod.
Most useful: Point of Interest search using Audi Connect.

BMW iDrive
Availability: Available standard or as an option on 1-series, 3-series, 5-series, 6-series, 7-series, X5, X6, and Z4 models.
Cost: Varies with model, up to $2,350 as a stand-alone option.
Favorite feature: The head-up navigation display.
Least favorite feature: Very structured commands.
Most useful: The extensive Point of Interest database.

Cadillac CUE
Availability: Available on 2013 XTS, ATS, and SRX models.
Cost: Standard for XTS and SRX, $1,350 option for ATS.
Favorite feature: Most flexible voice commands of the bunch.
Least favorite feature: Lackluster Point of Interest database.
Most useful: Intuitive music commands.

Hyundai Bluelink
Availabilty: Available in the 2013 Genesis Coupe and 2012 Avenza, Sonata, and Veloster models.
Cost: Varies by model, up to $2,900 as part of the Sonata's technology package.
Favorite feature: Very easy control to control Bluetooth-connected phone through voice commands.
Least favorite feature: No voice selection of music from iPod.
Most useful: Attractive screen, larger than others in its class.

Toyota Entune
Availability: Available in 4Runner, Camry, Corolla, Land Cruiser, Prius, RAV4, Sequoia, Sienna, Tacoma, Tundra, and Venza models.
Cost: Varies by model, a $1,015 stand-alone option.
Favorite feature: Entune can piggy-back on your iPhone's internet to search Bing and make dinner reservations through OpenTable.
Least favorite: Buttons surrounding touch screen were a little confusing.
Most useful: The very long (three-year) free trial period.

MyFord Touch
Availability: Available on Explorer, Escape, Expedition, E-Series, F-150, Transit Connect, Flex, Edge, C-MAX, Fusion, Focus, Mustang, Taurus, and Fiesta models.
Cost: Varies by model, part of a $2,000 package in some models.
Favorite feature: Easy control of audio system.
Least favorite feature: Inconsistent responses to voice commands.
Most useful: Has more features and capabilities than many other systems in its class.

title: Beyond Sync at Ford
promoTeaserSmall: New aftermarket devices are in the works to make your Ford as unique as you are.
promoTeaser: New aftermarket devices are in the works to make your Ford as unique as you are.
metaTitle: Beyond Sync at Ford - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Beyond Sync at Ford: Learn more about Ford's latest foray into car personalization at JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Ford has a new office in Silicon Valley, and they aren’t drawing pictures of cars on the walls. At the Silicon Valley Lab (or SVL, in Ford shorthand) the focus is programming. Specifically, the lab is focusing on the future of customizable, programmable automobiles.

Ford SYNC is already available in all 2013 Ford models, and features AppLink, one of Ford’s forays into in-car connectivity and personalization. The feature is able to manage certain mobile apps (like Pandora, Stitcher, NPR News, Slacker Radio, MLB.com, and other radio-based apps) through voice commands. AppLink allows drivers to request a mobile app and station, providing a hands-free way to control the radio in your car. One non-radio based app can provide allergy sufferers with real-time information about outdoor allergens and pollen levels.

Building on SYNC, Ford has launched an open source research and development project in conjunction with the developers at Bug Labs. The project, called OpenXC, currently operates only as a research arm, with development taking place at the University of Michigan, MIT, and Stanford University, as well as some development firms.

The hope is that in the future, the project will allow customers to achieve a high level of customization in their vehicles. Using an after-market device that plugs in to the car’s master control board (collaborator Bug Labs already designs them), customers can choose and change apps at their discretion. Ford would sell the devices, loaded with apps, at dealerships.

Ford has been mum so far about what type of applications exactly could result from the project, but seemingly the possibilities are almost limitless. If a developer can code it, and if Ford approves it, you can have it in your car. An Indian company has already completed an app that tracks the vehicle’s GPS position and rate of travel. It can also alert your contacts if you are running late for a meeting. If that seems a little too “Big Brother” to you, it’s probably best to focus on ideas like a fuel economy tracker or customized local radio stations.

Ford hopes that the research will lead to an affordable solution for drivers with constantly changing tastes and appetites for connectivity and technology, especially in markets like Asia, where Ford is less aware of the needs and desires of consumers. As this is the first such project, it remains to be seen how successful the OpenXC project will be, but if it distracts consumers from MyFord Touch, it’s already on the right track.

title: Seen at SEMA: Easy Scratch Fixer
promoTitle: Seen at SEMA: Easy Scratch Fixer
promoTeaserSmall: Stickerfix decals work, and they're as inexpensive and as easy to use as a set of Colorforms.
promoTeaser: Stickerfix decals work, and they're as inexpensive and as easy to use as a set of Colorforms.
metaTitle: Seen at SEMA: Easy Scratch Fixer -- JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Seen at SEMA: Easy Scratch Fixer. Read about a scratch-fixing decal product from Europe at JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Remember Colorforms? They were thin pieces of plastic die-cut into colorful shapes that you could arrange on a special coated surface and make them stick without an adhesive. Well, Stickerfix decals for your car feel and look very similar. The difference is that they go on a scratch on your car’s body. Once applied, you really can’t even spot them unless you are really searching.

We saw the Stickerfix decals in action on a bright red Fiat 500 at the Specialty Equipment Market Association trade show in Las Vegas this week. We learned that you can buy a set of the decals in any of seventy-nine colors, and that they are made using actual automotive paint so they match—the reps said—80 percent of cars on the road. For example, there’s Ford Light Ice Blue, there’s Honda Taffeta White, there’s Toyota Bronze and Volkswagen Tornado Red, but there’s also Universal Black. All the sticker packs cost $24.99 retail, and they contain a set of die-cut, easy-to-use shapes including circles, ovals, and long narrow scratch-shaped rectangles. A fuller explanation and a search function to find sales outlets is on the company's website.

You simply clean the scratched area on your car with a clean, soft cloth, then put the decal on, and you’re done.
That's great, because really, who wants to mess around with paint or pay somebody big bucks to cover something small and insignificant? This is an example of a great simple product that can cover a multitude of sins.

title: SEMA: Touchscreen Gloves
promoTeaserSmall: From Canada--where else?--come gloves that keep hands protected but still let you use a touchscreen.
promoTeaser: From Canada--where else?--come gloves that keep hands protected but still let you use a touchscreen.
metaTitle: SEMA: Touchscreen Gloves - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: SEMA: Touchscreen Gloves: Read about a line of gloves that allow your fingertips to use touchscreens, at JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: It's a peculiarly modern dilemma for those of us who live in cold climates: how to scroll through the iPhone while wearing gloves? As for me, I spend an inordinate amount of time pulling on gloves, yanking them off, and then pulling them on again. A Canadian company, appropriately enough, has a lineup of reasonably priced gloves that solve that problem. We spotted their Slide 'Em touchscreen-friendly gloves at the Specialty Equipment Market Association (SEMA) trade show in Las Vegas.

The trick in these gloves--a brand-new product just unveiled in September--is their thin fabric over the fingertips, which contrasts with the heavy-duty sturdiness of the rest of the glove. Now that touchscreens are starting to proliferate inside cars, it's going to be more important than ever to keep those fingertips free to do the job.

The gloves come in traditional black, safety glove green, and an array of bright colors. The company says it designed them to be "detailed crazy," and to you and me that means they are decidedly wild and immediately recognizable. Depending on your fashion style, this may or may not suit you, but it will definitely suit your need to access Facebook while you're out in the cold with your phone.
They gloves are available on the Slide 'Em website starting at a reasonable $34.95.

I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad.

pageElements.text: High fashion may not be the first thing that comes to mind when you think of the 2013 Malibu, but don’t tell that to the folks at Chevrolet. The brand has teamed up with designer Isaac Mizrahi to create a six-piece clothing collection designed with the Malibu in mind.

Chevrolet expects that women will be important to the new 2013 Malibu’s sales. Mary Kubitskey, advertising manager for the Malibu,  said that working with Mizrahi on the collection has helped Chevy “speak to women who embrace style, but still want a smart product to make their lives easier.” In a video for Chevrolet, Mizrahi said that he tries to create “beautiful, wonderfully indulgent things for smart women.”

If Chevy is looking to attract savvy buyers to its $23,150 Malibu, Isaac Mizrahi is the man to do it. Mizrahi has made a name for himself designing trendy clothes for the everyday buyer. He teamed up with Target for an affordable collection in the early 2000s before moving on to revamp the Liz Claiborne brand.

Mizrahi designed six pieces for the Malibu-inspired collection, which drew heavily on the car’s colors and textures. The blue pieces in the collection were born of the Malibu’s blue interior lighting, while red elements echo the Crystal Red Tintcoat exterior color (coincidence that Mizrahi chose to highlight an extra-cost paint color?). Available leather interior touches are showcased with a “buttery” leather coat and driving moccasins.

The items in the collection are priced from $70 to $300 and include red skinny jeans, a blue leather tote bag, a black leather jacket, an oversize watch, a robin’s-egg-blue blouse, and the aforementioned red leather driving moccasins. The items went on sale October 16 exclusively on LivingSocial, an online marketplace that posts deals on various items.
It may not be every girl who wants to color-match her sedan, but isn’t it nice to know you have the option?

title: Mini and Wool Make Knitting Cool With Scarf Kit Collaboration
promoTitle: Mini and Wool Make Knitting Cool With Scarf Kit Collaboration
promoTeaserSmall: Be true to your Mini with a True Blue Metallic Wool and the Gang scarf!
promoTeaser: Be true to your Mini with a True Blue Metallic Wool and the Gang scarf!
metaTitle: Knitting Kit to Match the Mini - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Mini and Wool Make Knitting Cool With Scarf Kit Collaboration: Read about a knitting kit to match the Mini Countryman at JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I don’t understand people who dislike driving. I really don't. The freedom of getting behind the wheel of a car and just taking off can't be compared with anything else. You really feel that you’re in charge: in charge of the car, in charge of the road, and in charge of your life. Why on earth would you want someone else to drive you around when you could do it yourself? It’s so liberating! Obviously, I love driving. I suppose that isn't a particularly original statement for a Detroit native, but it's true. I was a little late getting my driver's license because of that pesky parallel parking, but once I got it, nothing could stop me. It doesn't matter if I have to chauffeur my grandmother to the bank less than a block from our house or drive across town. If I have my green Chrysler LHS--affectionately christened "Betsy" by my mother--and some gas in the tank, and if I am somehow able to avoid getting pulled over for driving just a little too fast, I'm good to go.

Since I graduated from the University of Michigan, in April 2012, Betsy has taken me everywhere. She has been my steadfast companion on trips to buy more supplies for various sewing projects, leisurely drives along Jefferson/Lakeshore Drive in Grosse Pointe Shores, Michigan, and frequent jaunts to the bookstore to buy yet another copy of Hamlet, a 500-plus-page book on Elizabeth I, or a good book on British history that isn’t as dry as a piece of chalk…And, yes, there is a little bit of theme there. Not only am I a bibliophile, but I’m also a self-proclaimed Anglophile who loves Shakespeare and Elizabethan verse and one day plans to see the Houses of Parliament, visit the Tower of London, and, perhaps most important, eat real fish and chips. If only I could drive Betsy "across the pond…"

pageElements.text: You can already match your clothes to your Chevy Malibu, but now your next knitting project (and resulting scarf) can match your 2013 Mini Cooper Countryman!
Wait.
Something about that doesn’t seem quite right, though, does it?
We know that we've explained to you that there is a definite link between cars and fashion, but cars and knitting?

It's true. The Munich-based car company would like you to knit after purchasing their limited-edition Mini & Wool and the Gang knitting kit, a by-product of a two-year partnership between Mini and the European yarn label Wool and the Gang which started with the Mini Countryman Open Air event in London where guests were able to “test knit” the label's knitting needles. The kit comes complete with everything you will need to knit and finish Wool and the Gang’s Lula Hoop scarf, including a pattern, a sewing needle, washing instructions, and two balls of the company’s 100 percent Peruvian “crazy sexy wool” in True Blue Metallic—a paint shade that is only available for the Countryman and the only color this kit comes in. You do have the option of ordering the kit with the required 15 mm straight knitting needles (that’s size 19 for those of us in the States. Definitely not your Grandma’s knitting needles) for $95 or without them for $75.
If you don’t knit and aren’t completely sure what all of this means, never fear. Knitting is the new-old hip thing to do and this kit is marketed to novice and advanced knitters alike.

As an avid knitter and fan of British television, I would be particularly pleased if Mini and Wool and the Gang designed a DIY knitting kit for making a replica of Mr. Bean’s best friend and accomplice, Teddy. (After all, isn’t Mr. Bean everyone’s favorite bumbling Mini owner?) But until that glorious day comes, go to the Wool and the Gang website to order your scarf kit, start your engines and get your needles clicking, just don’t do everything at the same time, please!

subTitle: Don't be wasting that gas money. I've got some easy ways for you to improve fuel economy.

metaDescription: Three Fuel-Economy Driving Tips: See my Tribune syndicate TV appearance in which she gives tips for better fuel economy--on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

metaDescription: Seen at SEMA: Three Arty Finds. Read about some awesome car accessories seen at the 2012 SEMA aftermarket show at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The annual trade show of the Specialty Equipment Market Association (SEMA) is a feast of spectacular custom cars mixed with acres of brakes, suspension components, and other less-than-fascinating but important products.  As JKC made its way through the aisles, we found a few great things we want to share with you.

Retro Accessories for Classics

We loved all three core products of Retro Manufacturing of Chino, California: seatbelts, audio systems, and especially antennas, all true to 1960s styling while meeting modern quality expectations. You probably wouldn’t buy these unless you were restoring (or still holding on to) a vehicle of the era, but we felt all kinds of nostalgia well up in us when we looked at these products.

The New Retro Classic radio, for example, looks for all the world like the original AM radio in a Sixties sedan, yet it has AM/FM and even an auxiliary input for your iPod. The Zuma radio has the authentic rectangular push buttons you might remember from back in the day, plus AM/FM tuner and the ability to play MP3s using a rear-mounted USB input.

The seatbelts come in twenty-three colors from bright red to turquoise, with chromed belt ends, and there are not only the two-point lap belts of yore, but also three-point belts and even four-point harnesses for the street, “great for open vehicles.”

The company’s Retrosound good old-fashioned collapsible antennas are intended for a variety of vintage Chevrolet and Ford vehicles from the 1950s through the early 1980s. There’s also a fully automatic power antenna that works with most vehicles, including import models, according to the folks at Retro. Jean reminisced about pulling the antennas on her parents’ cars up and down, up and down, until they didn’t work anymore. Her five brothers may have been involved as well.

Shift Knobs that Approach Art Status

Two companies we saw sold replacement shift knobs. If you’re going to drive a car with a stick shift, which you know JKC is in favor of, a little attitude wouldn’t be out of place. NR-G Innovations from City of Industry, California, had both ball and oblong shapes in carbon fiber, shiny, and matte finishes, and there’s an awesome two-tone option with a contrasting-color ring around the top.

The American Shifter Company from Portland, Oregon, takes that a step further with the ability to put a personal message on the shift knob. At the show stand, they had iPads set up to let show goers try this out. We weren’t totally sure we would get “Jean Knows Cars” on the shift knob of our car, but it was amusing to think about. In the premade category, there were multicolor glass knobs that looked like Christmas ornaments and bizarre novelty items including skulls, fez-wearing monkey, “Taz the Charging Goat,” and even a stick of dynamite. Not sure who would buy these, or what they would be thinking when they did. Well, maybe the Flying Eye Ball might get the nod, as long as it was easy to replace after the novelty wore off….

Craziest Helmets Ever

If you’ve ever tried to get a preteen into a helmet to go biking or skateboarding, or if you just appreciate fine headgear the way Jean does, you’ve got to appreciate the horn-oriented style of Horny Mike and his Horny Helmet Accessories. We met Mike, Jean tried on his helmets, and they bonded over the discovery that he is from the downriver area of Michigan.

Beyond the wild art helmets on display at SEMA on on his website, his real product is sets of lightweight horns that stick on to your existing helmet. They’re made from ABS plastic, are three and a half inches tall, and have been tested to stay on at 200 mph, Mike says. Two come in a set—in colors including chrome, black, lime green, red, or pink—but you could get four for a Mohawk/stegosaurus look, or stick them all over a helmet for true head-turning style.
