metaTitle: 5 Black Friday Deals for the Car - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 5 Black Friday Deals for the Car: Go to JeanKnowsCars.com to see a few post-Black Friday deals we've found for car products.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: I spend the day after Thanksgiving the way all good Americans should: eating coney dogs and drinking beer with my family. I’ve never been shopping on Black Friday, and I never want to go. Luckily, there are good deals available once that melee has ended, both online and in stores. Here are a few we located.

Navigation System

If you’re driving an older car and are envious of the in-dash nav systems in new models, now is the perfect time for an upgrade. While you can’t swap out your center console for something more modern, you can buy a cheap, handy, portable GPS device that will get you from A to B and might even save you some heated discussions about directions. Best Buy has several models, including a Garmin model that you see at the top of the page. It has maps of the lower forty-eight and lifetime map updates, as well as text-to-speech directions, for $99.99, a savings of $35.

images.caption: Portable DVD player, one of several at Target.
In-dash audio.
Hands-free device for the car sets up a Bluetooth connection.
Who doesn't need a small, tidy jump-start kit?

pageElements.text:
In-Dash Radio

A shiny new radio is another way to bring an aging automobile into the twenty-first century. Buying a new radio, which can be plopped right into your dash in place of the old one, can give you access to a whole new world of media. Not only will you have good old AM/FM at your fingertips, many new radios can connect to MP3 players and include USB ports to give you access to your digital music collection. Walmart is currently offering a Boss Audio in-dash radio with AM/FM radio, a CD player, MP3 compatibility, and a USB port for $49.00, a savings of $20.99.

Portable DVD Player

If visual stimulation is what your car is missing, look no further than Target’s sale papers. The retailer is offering several portable DVD players at steep discounts, which could be just the thing to help pass the time on long car trips. Target is selling an RCA seven-inch DVD player with dual screens that strap to the back of a headrest, mimicking integrated entertainment systems. That gadget will cost just $59 online, offering customers a saving of $70. Target is also running sales on larger, laptop-style DVD players. One such product has a nine-inch screen and will be on sale for $55 instead of its usual $124.

Hands-Free Kit

Several states now have laws that require drivers to use hands-free devices when making phone calls. This is fine if you’re driving a new or nearly new car, many of which come with standard Bluetooth connectivity. But if your car is more mature, a hands-free kit can help you avoid a pesky ticket. For just $37.71 (down from $79.99) Amazon will sell you a device that plugs into a car’s cigarette lighter and generates a Bluetooth connection that will allow you to talk on the phone, braid your hair, and drive the car all at the same time. (Just kidding.)

Jump-Start Kit

After I got my driver’s license in my junior year of high school, I started staying back after cross country practice to make sure all of my teammates had rides home. This also meant that I was the jump starter of choice for girls who had forgotten to turn off their headlights and had run out the batteries in their car. You wouldn’t believe how often this happened. If you’ve got an absent-minded driver in the family, you can save people like me a lot of trouble by buying them a portable Jump-Start system. It's not as heavy duty as the ones AAA will use if you call them when your battery dies in a drive-in parking lot, but it can make the difference between stranded and started in a pinch. These kits can be charged in a wall outlet and then used to jump a car battery in just a few minutes, offering peace of mind if you or loved ones are traveling in remote or dangerous areas. Amazon is running a sale on one model by Energizer marked down to $108.95 from $149.99.
No matter what type of car gear you’re looking for, you can probably find it among the many, many deals offered by retailers for the kick off of this holiday shopping season. Just don’t get trampled!

title: 18 Reasons to Road Trip with a Teen
promoTitle: 18 Reasons to Road Trip with a Teen
promoTeaserSmall: They're not getting any younger. Before that 18th year tolls, make like Kerouac and go off together.
promoTeaser: They're not getting any younger. Before that 18th year tolls, make like Kerouac and go off together.
metaTitle: 18 Reasons to Go on a Road Trip with Your Teenager - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: why you should travel with teenagers
metaDescription: There are 18 reasons to go on a road trip with your teenage children, and you will find them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: In the summer of 2009, hearing the clock ticking on parenthood and keenly observing the growing independence of my children, I had the crazy idea of a road trip. I talked it over with the family and decided I would drive from Michigan to California and back with my two teenage sons. Max was sixteen, Henry had just turned fourteen, and I wanted them to learn to love travel. Besides, I wanted to go on a major road trip myself.
It was only half our family: the kids' other parent and two younger siblings weren't invited this time. That added to the specialness of going on the trip for my boys, I think.

We drove 6,800 miles in two weeks, passing through South Dakota, turning south and going through Colorado into New Mexico. Next we meandered across northern Arizona and visited both the Grand Canyon and the hippie boarding school in Sedona from which I graduated in 1974, where they had never been. After a 115-degree desert crossing, we bore north to San Francisco, then took the northern route back through Utah and Montana. We had no itinerary, no hotel reservations, and no specific goals. We didn't even have GPS, only a pile of maps and a copy of The Next Stop, an occasionally useful guidebook to what you can find at highway exits nationwide. It wasn't what you'd call an organized trip, but then, my traveling companions weren't what you'd call neat, tidy, or inclined to worry about itinerary changes.

As our minivan pulled back into the driveway just before school started that fall, I felt closer and more connected to my boys than I had since they were babies. I also felt some pride that together, my boys and I powered through boredom, logistical problems, fatigue, fear of heights, and disagreements to have a really, really good time traveling together.
I had no trouble thinking up eighteen reasons why this kind of road trip is a great idea:

images.caption: Max at Mount Rushmore.
The unmissable stop at Wall Drug in South Dakota.
Another Wall Drug tourist attraction.
Henry (left) and Max did a lot of out-of-car running around.
Somewhere east of Laramie.
Most luxurious hotel we stayed in.
On the Four Corners monument, poised over Colorado.
External temperature was 115 degrees.
Irony is everywhere if you travel with teenagers.
On the grounds of Verde Valley School in Arizona, my alma mater.
The guys were in charge of loading and unloading the car.

pageElements.text:
1. Something for you.

You have been putting off traveling to somewhere because you were busy raising kids. Go there, and bring them along.

2. Clock is ticking.

You only have a couple more years of being their day-to-day parent; stick them in the car and go while you still have the authority to do so.

3. Opportunity to talk.

You already know that traveling in the car with your teenagers is the time when you have the best conversations.

4. Training-wheels version of On the Road.

Teenagers are at the most creative time of life, and at the time of life when they are most inclined to take risks. An extended drive with you is a safer, more controlled outlet for adventure on the road than when they will (soon) be doing it alone.

5. Starter course to a life of exploration.

Think of an extended drive as an appetizer that will make them hungry to go explore new places—and you can show them the skills they’ll need to do it.

6. Rediscover your own kids.

You will be showing your kids that you want to spend time with them. You will rediscover that you actually do want to spend time with them.

7. Let them get to know you as a human being.

You will make mistakes and get lost; this will make you a more three-dimensional character to your children. In my case, I had a serious case of fear of heights trying to go through Rocky Mountain National Park. It was stressful, but I felt closer to my boys after it happened, especially after we didn’t go over the edge and crash.

8. Opportunity to learn.

You can back up a book they’re reading or a subject they’re studying with educational (not too educational) side trips or pilgrimages.

9. Opportunity to see family.

Build in an overnight visit or two to far-flung relatives or friends as part of the trip. Bonus: saves hotel $. We spent a night in San Francisco with my friend’s mother, whom my children had never met. My friend was nowhere nearby (she lives in Brooklyn). My friend’s mom was lonely; it was a blast; the boys loved her. She passed away a year later, so that turned out to have been our one chance.

10. Lots of reading together.

Long drives let you listen to books on CD. Be like the commercial where the two guys learn fluent Spanish on a road trip, or do what we did and listen to all of Roots on CD. (Started in Michigan; listened to the final chapter in New Mexico. Then 1984 on the way home.) I know people who read entire books aloud to their family members while on a trip; that would drive me nuts, but YMMV.

11. Learn to trust their judgment.

Let your kids make as many of the travel plans as possible, including route, destination, and a wish list of sights. Example: my middle son’s main request was to see Mt. Rushmore. That was our first stop, and we planned our drive west around it.

12. See schools and scout locations.

If your children are ready to consider where to go to college, use this as a chance to make informal trips to colleges and especially to college towns. We swung through the hip pedestrian malls of Iowa City and gave the guys a whole new way of looking at what they had thought of as an agrarian state. But keep a road trip separate from a college trip or you will taint the experience.

13. Eat foods you wouldn’t normally.

Go to regional restaurants rather than chains; stop at roadside stands; and my favorite, scout out a diner in small town stops, the one where they look at you strangely because they don’t know you and it’s unexpected to see non-locals walk in. Plus, what the heck, let them eat sunflower seeds and Pringles in the car and drink Big Gulps. They’re teenagers.

14. Shop with a teenager’s eye for irony.

Collect something cheap that will be fun to have later, such as guitar-case stickers or postcards (we hit the jackpot at a fuel stop in desert California where there were retro car stickers from every state). Bring home rattlesnake jerky or Moon Pies.

15. Get off the Interstate.

When you can, take the Blue Highways and see what the region is really like. The remoteness and tedium of driving across New Mexico and Arizona’s reservation lands was perhaps the most memorable stretch of our drive because it was utterly unlike anything at home.

16. Force sibling interaction.

If you've got more than one teenager on the trip, there's the bonus (sometimes the problem) of their own travel relationship. Siblings who played together for hours a day in elementary school may drift apart as teens. They will forge a new chapter in their relationship if they spend two weeks in the car together. Hint: Drive a minivan or SUV that gives each of them some personal space; be a uniter, not a torturer.

17. Rack up driving hours.

If your kids have their permits and need highway experience, if they’re cocky new drivers and need lots of hours with you as a back-seat driver, or if they are already excellent drivers and can give you long breaks from driving during a trip, those are all good things.

18. Life is short, people.

It is really so short. Press Pause on your life and those of your kids and go somewhere together.
Just as your parenting experience isn't really over at age eighteen, this list isn't quite over yet, either. Here are...

Three cardinal rules to keep your expectations grounded.


19. Don’t expect complete harmony.

They’ll be bored and crabby sometimes; you’ll be impatient and crabby sometimes. Accept it now, and hold the fake cheerfulness to a strict minimum.

20. Don’t make everything into a learning experience.

They won’t care about the historical significance of some location you’ve been looking forward to, or they will want to leave a place you thought they were going to adore. Get over it.

21. Don’t try to make this the One Life-Changing Trip.

If life is a banquet, taking your kids on a driving trip should be more like grazing than stuffing yourselves. See what you see, and get as far as you get, and enjoy that.
